reviewText:
Reviewing a remake of a game that is over ten years old is a little difficult, especially if the remake is nearly an exact copy of the original game.  In this case, “Age of Mythology: Extended Edition” is nearly identical.  Everything from the character models to the level design remain the same.  Don’t get me wrong, it looks much prettier than I remember it…but aside from the extras, you’re getting the same game you played years prior.  Same scoop of vanilla ice cream if you will, but with jimmies and chocolate syrup on top.  Shadows, lighting, water effects, time of day, antialiasing, ambient occlusion…all great additions, I just wish there was a bit more.  Twitch users will be pleased to know that there is Twitch integration, though I personally haven’t tried it to know if it works.

With that being said, I do appreciate the remake, even if it’s almost the same game as I played years ago.  Seeing the updated graphics was nice, though I admit the appeal was mainly centered around the fact that I didn’t have to enter my blasted serial key each time I wanted to install the game.  I also don’t have to worry about managing discs…all three products (“Age of Mythology”, “Age of Mythology: The Titans”, “Golden Gift Campaign”) were all condensed into one nice, easy to boot up package.  It’s hard to justify that convenience into a thirty dollar price tag however, the going rate as of 4/29/14.  If you’ve never played “Age of Mythology”, love RTS’s, and don’t mind the outdated character models/interface, then picking this up is most certainly worth your time and money. If you have your own playable copies of the game from years ago and want to know if buying the extended edition for the effects is worth thirty bucks, then I’d have to say (with heartfelt regret) no.

reviewText:
Age of Mythology is the classic, mythology based spinoff of Age of Empires, and boy was it fun. But does Age of Mythology  Extended Edition live up to the original? In many ways, very much so, though the price tag might dissaude you unless you're a huge fan, (like I am).

If you've played Age of Mythology before, you know exactly how this game works. If not, here a basic gist of it. It plays much like Age of Empires 2; you have to collect resources, specifically food, wood and gold, in order to fund your armies, economies, technologies and advancement. sounds basic enough, and all the races work similarly in regards to these resources. The difference comes in the fourth resource: Favour. Favour is generated differently depending on which race you are playing. For instance, the greeks generate favour through worship, the egyptians through building monuments, the norse through heroes and fighting, and the atlanteans through having more settlements.

Favour is the special resource, which ties into the major mechanic of Age of Mythology: Gods and God Powers. There are 12 major gods, 3 for each of the races, and these determine starting bonuses for you when you start the game. the gods also have minor gods to choose each time you advance an age, with a total of 36 minor gods, each offering different bonuses and god powers. For instance Hades gives you the Sentinel God Power, that creates stone sentinels to watch over your town centre, but in the second age, you can choose Athena, who allows you to train minotaurs and the Restoration God power which can heal your units.

Aside from the new favour mechanic, for the major part it plays like the age of empires games. Build Army, upgrade, and take care of your population cap and economy. Rock paper scissors, for basic units, (cavalry beats archers who beat infantry), but add heroes and myth units which can turn the tide of battle. Both the singleplayer and multiplayer are fun, and with the new release, there is a rebirth in the multiplayer, though not as big as the heyday of AoM.

As being essentially a remake (a la Age of Empires 2 HD Edition), AoM:EE is actually fairly bug free, and while it definitely shows its age, the added subtle lighting effects, water and shadows do help to make look better. It is definitely very playable, and for fans of the original, it shouldn't even be a bother.

The campaign is just as memeroable as always, a hunt through Greece, Egypt, Scandinavia and finally Atlantis in order to stop a power hungry cyclops from releasing Kronos, King of the Titans; followed by A New Atlantis, set a number of years later,  where you are tricked into releasing the Titans, and must stop them at all costs .

Overall, Age of Mythology: Extended Editon is fun, unique and offers up plenty of value, with 50 singleplayer missions, skrimishes, and now revived multiplayer, though for those who still have a copy of Age of Mythology and The Titans expansion, it might not add a great deal. Definitely recommend everyone else (who's a fan of older RTSes).

reviewText:
Ordinarily, I don't write reviews - but I've always been pretty invested in the Ensemble Studios games and seeing what Microsoft and Skybox have done with one of their all-time legends has pushed me into comment.

Age of Mythology: Extended Edition. Ordinarily, to extend something means to prolong it or make it bigger somehow but if you're hoping for new content, this game does not have any. It's just the same game you played back in 2003 - but that's not so bad, because that game was great. This however, isn't - and there's some vital reasons as to why:

1 - The Multiplayer.
The most important aspect of any Real Time Strategy game is its multiplayer community and Age of Mythology has always had a creative and thriving one. This Extended Edition would too - if the multiplayer actually worked. You don't need me to tell you, just go check out the Support forum for this game. The game suffers from consistent crashes, desync, stuttering, framedrops and lag when attempting an online game. The developers blame ancient bugs" left over from the original game despite the fact that none of these bugs were actually present in the 2003 release and accusing the now defunct Ensemble Studios (thanks Microsoft) for being responsible for your own mistakes is downright cowardly. disrespectful and lazy especially seeing as you're now flogging their product to an unaware market.

2 - The Single Player.

reviewText:
As you see I've spent over 600 hours playing this game, and that is not even a lot when you compare it to the time I played the original game for. Definitely had to re-write my review since my other one was made after 30 gameplay hours.

Age of Mythology takes you into one of the most unique and timeless RTS experiences I have ever seen. You have to pick between 4 civilizations: the Greek, Egyptian, Norse and Atlantean - each have 3 major gods to pick from. There are 4 ages to guide your civilization through, each of which unlocks new buildings, upgrades and units.  Each of these presents you with two choices for minor gods that you can worship. Every time you choose a god(including the major god), you will unlock a god power that can be used only once (up to 3 times if you're Atlantean) as well as a mythological creature or two that are associated with your god choice + unique upgrades. These god powers can change the tide of the game entirely.


Each civilization is completely different in their design, and there can be differences between identical major gods as well thanks to the minor god system.
The units classes featured are infantry, cavalry, archers, siege, heroes, mythological creatures and ships. The game makes these interact in a rock-paper-sciccor mechanic.

The campaign is very high quality for its time, it can be highly entertaining even now, though. A total of around 50 missions is more than any RTS game will give you. The voice acting is great, though the dialouge and the plot get cheesy at points.

Graphically, the shadows, the water improvements, the map texture improvements are nice, but they cannot hide the dated models and textures. I wish those had been areas of focus when it comes to visual improvements. The lighting is terrible in a few cases, so I would recommend turning the lights on units" option off
date: as it's the worst of all new features. FXAA and water refraction aren't too helpful either

reviewText:
I wrote a review for this a while back, and I can say with confidence many issues have been sorted out, but some are still persistent.

If you have never played this game, I am going to say right now to buy this game and play it. The campaign and its storyline is great, the factions are unique and well fleshed out and balance, for the most part, is achieved with some minor discrepencies/exploits which with experience can be learned to be countered.

I will say that the game is not in its glory days anymore as this IS a re-release of a fairly old title. But the multiplayer is also active enough to have a competitive community and there is a revival in the scenario community to experience a taste of the legacy of AoM mapmakers, I suggest looking on http://aom.heavengames.com/downloads/ for more or the Steam workshop downloads provided.


But lets start with the actual meat of the game for anyone reading for determining whether to buy this:

The Extended Edition brings many new improvements over old Age of Mythology and the Titans expansion included, water and other graphics are overhauled and improved significantly. Graphics in general have been improved over the original and the game looks much more vibrant and detailed. This makes playing the singleplayer campaign, which is still one of the better campaigns of an RTS I have played, much more enjoyable.

A new online server is also available for multiplayer gameplay and while its nowhere even close to the glory days of ESO in terms of activity and the amount of scenario makers, some old faces are there both in competitive gameplay and with old mapmakers, and some newer map makers such as myself have been sprouting up. In terms of connection these days it really depends on whose actually in the game but as long as you're computer isn't a toaster your connection and running of this game should go forward without a hitch.

However there is still some bugs that are highly irritating that remain. Desync errors still happen too frequently for my tastes and this wouldn't be so much a problem if it didn't lower the rating of those involved in ranked matches. When someone is on the verge of victory and then a desync error occurs to make them lose rating... its understandable someone would be angry.

There is also more visible lag and connection issues between players then there was on the old AoM in certain instances, such as on certain scenarios or with people with very bad connection to begin with. And the Extended Edition is notable in how it actually lags your computer- some of us may remember we could browse the internet with Age of Mythology running in windowed mode or running other programs while we wait for a game; while this isn't prevented and is still possible the speed of which you do so is stifling and I would not recommend it at all now. (Nor would I recommend it in matches even back then, but if you're in lobby just idling, waiting for your friend to host that game...)

I suggest if you are buying this, do not play on your toaster or similar dinosaur computer, this is an updated version of Age of Mythology meant to be played on semi modern machines.

And as for scenario editors who wish to return to making maps for this game: The online multiplayer community is in desperate need of scenario revival. There is scenarios still being played from time to time but the newer population of competitive players is either unaware of most of the maps or simply do not host them, mostly the former. As for the editor itself, for all intents and purposes its more or less the same as what we know, but there is some notable differences now.

The differences boil down to some old trigger techniques not working, and now causing horrible lag. The old trick of looping Move Army To to move your spawned units to a location, looping it within the trigger editor now causes horrible lag and no longer just simply makes them keep moving there. It acts as if the computer stops their units and tells them to move there, acting as if the loop was just restarting and stopping the order instead of merely continuing it as it did in the past.

There is also UI changes to the editor, and while the function is largely the same it takes a bit getting used to. I can say with confidence though the editor is still fairly user friendly and easy to learn, though trying to find experienced mappers to help you with your project is a little difficult in terms of looking on the lobby- you'll have to consult various forums like AoM heaven or pitch it on the steam forums for this game somewhere. I myself can help with things too, and even old legends like Nottud are still around if you look...

So it boggles down to this, overall: Should you buy this game if you are new, and should you buy this game if you already have age of mythology, the original and its expansion, to relive your nolstalgia?

If you are new, refer to the top. Yes.
If you are an old and musty returning player like me, Yes, but don't expect it to be total brass and shine throughout the entire game. There is some grime to be worked out with this still but I can say with confidence there has been legitimate work and attention on this game to improve it and fix bugs.

(p.s Potato, if you review my review im going to shoot you and feed you to a chimera, not only was your review pointless, it was awful in its critique and if anything uninformative. No one cares about grammar to that extent, it's all about presentation, and the clarity of my review was fine. That is all :D )

reviewText:
Pixel Judge Age of Mythology: Extended Edition review

The Verdict
Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is a very good cash-in on an old game. RTS market isn‘t really oversaturated and AoMEE is still a solid game. Two good (and one less so) campaigns that are bundled together with really fun skirmish, and all of that is topped by an excellent map editor, and now, Steam Workshop integration. What else could one ask? Surely not a sequel, because it would suck.

Score: 4.5/5 - Still a legendary game.

Full review and appeals - http://www.pixeljudge.com/en/reviews/age-of-mythology-extended-edition/

reviewText:
While an old game now I still have fun jumping on it here and there and having a few games with friends of against the AI. For people who have yet to play this game, don't be put off by the mythological theme.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=353515238
This is still a great game that will give you the same satisfaction that you have gotten from the other titles.

The campaign is fun and quite a lengthy investment. The expansion added campaign following the original is fantastic as well. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=353515278
You can live without the dwarves focused one, while it has some fun ideas for maps it's short, easy and lacks any real depth . The main problem I had with these in the newest steam version was that the graphical quality seems to have been dramatically reduced.

The day and night cycle is over rated and really serves no point, if anything I found it broke the game up more and turned it off.

Multiplayer is fun but expect to play against strong players. Random AI matches are the same as before but with two new game types. They can be fun but I've always been a conquest or occasionally supremacy fan.

Overall it's basically the same game that it was in the past.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=353515262
The steam community seems to have produced a nice array of new mods to enjoy and I've had fun revisiting this game once again. If you are considering repurchasing this game, wait for a sale and pick it up cheap, it's the same game. If you are looking at this game for the first time and enjoy similar games in the age of" series you should enjoy this title and get your money's worth from it but it may seem a little dated at first."

reviewText:
I was fooled by myself, thinking this would be a great Extension to AOM, I feel that the developers and the people who worked on this (Sky box) have cashed in, knowing people will buy this regardless if they polish it well or badly because of nostalgia and the sly meta critic score that was taken from the original release several years ago. They knew there were going to be problems with this game upon release, it is disgusting to think that any company would release a product which is not up to scratch especially since the game was already released. I didn't pay the already expensive price to play a beta of a game that already exists. They have not delivered in my opinion, the AI is still terrible, the Multiplayer is lagging (reason I bought this game) and the frame rate is questionable for a game like this, the lighting effects are nothing special if not distracting and the menus are different (compared to the originals) but either way, re-mastered or not, the menus fulfilled their purpose, to be menus. I don't see how this warrants at £20 price tag. To make matters worse me and my friends are encountering problems with the steam overlay which is hindering our multiplayer experience. The steam workshop is also not working.
I do not recommend buying this until the price drops and the problems with it are fixed, I will not trust this company again I thought AOE2 should have been a good indication of how they handle projects like these, I feel silly to have used the benefit of the doubt.

Age of Mythology (when it is working) however is an excellent strategy game for competitive play, the multiplayer is excellent and the different civilizations are unique in terms of units, technologies and strategies that can be applied, it makes for a fresh experience on an age old formula, If only they continued after Age of Empires 3.

reviewText:
If you are looking for a multiplayer RTS, and your internet speed isn't incredible, move along. That said, if you are interested in single player or have amazing internet connection, go right ahead.

In Short - There is a compounded latency issue. Animation quality is directly proportional to connection quality. One player with a bad connection (Or a large number of players) will slow your game. And when it slows down your game, it slows down everything causing animations to lag and glitch. They’ve updated the server client code in the Extended Edition, where they didn't need to (causing terrible bugs).

In Long: Instead of a dedicated server setup. AOM now uses a peer to peer connection. The Pros are that you don't need to create servers, or port forward. But the downside is that the next iteration of the game cannot continue until every player has received information from every other player.
This means that with more players, more information is required to be sent before a game iteration occurs. Additionally, with one player with a high latency, that latency affects every single player within the game. Currently with this problem, AOM game speed slows down, affecting EVERY SINGLE ELEMENT OF GAMEPLAY. This includes MODEL ANIMATION (Imagine bad connection = laggy and glitchy character models).

However, this game would have been fine it they either:
When the game speed is slowed down, change the timings of the model animations to match the new game speed (Just play on lightning speed to compensate).
…Or just kept the old dedicated server engine for AOM.

It saddens me that I cannot play this game reasonably with my friends, and I don’t want others to be disappointed. Considering that we all pre-paid, none of us can get a refund for the game we bought. That said, if you are interested in single player or have amazing internet connection, go right ahead.

reviewText:
Age of Mythology: EE is a reprise of the oldschool AoM: Titans, incorporating many online features thanks to the Steam platform the game manages to come back to life easing out the task of playing with other players around the world which is always a refreshing thing to do when it comes to replaying really oldschool games.

Graphically the improvs of the game aren't as shocking as the multiple previews we had through the years this was being announced, but its something, and its nice, decent.

The game on its core is better balanced, and the gameplay has some nifty improvements to offer.

The main issue is the performance.

Somehow the game manages to run poorly on most systems, with huge frame drops, and the games unability to run from certain common graphic cards, and only from integrated graphics. Which drops the framerate and overall responsiveness even more. To the point that is actually hard to enjoy.

Even if there aren't much changes graphically/gameplay wise to be called Extended Edition" its a shame such cool online features are being hindered by the inability to correctly address the performance issues that were promised to be tackled since the launch itself.

If you really enjoy RTS games
recommended: and you're sure your system's performance will overcome the game issues then you will have a good time.\n\nOtherwise. Stay Away."

reviewText:
TL:DR version - I like age of mythology as a game, but this remake kind of sucks.

TL:ohgawdwhyareyoustilltalking version...

Alright, let's start with what makes age of mythology great! As a game, it's wonderful and has stood the test of time. You have a wide array of very different strategies and tactics you can use, the different races all feel substantially unique from one another, and you can pick various major and minor deities to worship which each tweak your play style to suit your individual preferences better!

The units are fairly unique from one another, there's lots of interesting mythological things like giants, pegasi, sphinxes and so on, and the economic aspects are rather enjoyable as well, which is rare for a strategy game. For an example of the economic stuff, look to the egyptians who can have their pharoah empower a building to make it build faster or boost the resources given to it, or that the atlanteans carry carts with them so they don't have to wander all the way back to town to drop off resources.

There's always sort of a rock/paper/scissors thing going on, and no one unit is overpowered... buuuuut. Ah, yeah, there's always a but isn't there? It's a big fat butt in this case. Several of them.

Well, some of what I just mentioned isn't super accurate. A lot of the units are very, very similar with little difference at all other than their stats - special abilities are pretty much reserved for mythological units and the god powers can only be invoked once per game instead of on a cooldown so they're not that impressive most of the time. Generally speaking, your units may look different and be better tasks, but one soldier is pretty much the same as any other soldier, other than what they do bonus damage against.

That's another issue... the balance" of the game

reviewText:
Age of Mythology: Extended Edition as a real-time strategy game published by Microsoft. It is a perfected version of the old game Age of Mythology and Age of Mythology: The Titans.

Age of Mythology: Extended Edition gameplay are pretty much the same as the old Age of Mythology and Age of Mythology: The Titans made into one game. In addition, the Golden Gift add on are also included in this remake. Unlike Age of Empires II: HD Edition, Age of Mythology: Extended Edition doesn't have population cap increase, everything in the gameplay stays the same. It's quite nostalgic to replay this old game with improved graphics, I remember almost all the god powers I used, the meteor rain, tornado, earthquake and more. Age of Mythology: Extended Edition also comes with Steam Cloud support and Steam Workshop support, which is a great addition into the game.

Age of Mythology: Extended Edition however, have improved graphics than the old game. New improved global lightning, widescreen support, new water shaders and the new day and night cycle in skirmish play. It looks prettier now and more epic to play. With all these improved visuals, Age of Mythology: Extended Edition still retain its great performances and runs very great and smooth.

Age of Mythology: Extended Edition exact same gameplay can be its good side or bad side for some people. But for me, it's very nostalgic and fun. I prefer this kind exact same gameplay rather than some of those next generation game with many promises which turn out to be a disappointment. Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is indeed a great remake. I recommend this.

Rating 9/10

reviewText:
There are many features which make the game great. I'm gonna name a few:

- beautiful randomly generated maps. You can learn everything you need to know about the maps in 2 hours, but even after 30 days of playing they will still surprise you.
- the playable cultures excel with their diversity and fascinating mythology. Unleash terrifying mythical brutes such as the einherjer which will tear your enemies apart.
- Advancing on the map with your siege army and military camps adds a lot to the 'all out war' feeling to the game.
- The soundtrack, the graphics and the overall design make for a true atmospheric environment.

Age of Mythology was the game that initally ignited my passion for online games. It's hard for me to be objective, because I share so many glorius childhood memories with this classic jewel. The main reason I bought the extended edition for steam were simple: The game hasn't aged and they gave access to online-playing. The former AoM servers were unfortunately shut down which was a huge bummer at the time.

reviewText:
At the current game state (as of 10/05/2014), the game handles like a donkey with broken legs; total trash. For (what seems to be) the majority of players, the game handles and runs poorly. Constant lagging, freezing and hanging that slows down the PC as a whole and can cause it to lock up.

I've tried many things for numerous hours to try and get this classic RTS to work. To name a few,
XP Compatibility, Admin mode, trouble-shooting with all sorts of options and settings in-game and in steam, folder read/write permission/rights, defragging, PC cleaning (registry files for example) and nothing made a difference. Sometimes right away or a couple minutes (at best) after I launch the game, the lag started and it just got worse and worse to the point where my whole PC would freeze up and I'd need to manually terminate the game exe' file through the Task Manager.

Bitter I may sound, and disappointed I am. I do not recommend purchasing this game as of yet. Perhaps (and hopefully) the game will be patched and fixed in the future. But as of yet; it isn't worth the gamble to see if you're part of the minority that can run the game just fine.

reviewText: Three trolls, four golden battle boars and a pack of wolves have just devastated the last of Thor's town centres, and my gatherers have already moved in to take over their farming network. I am Odin, and my thunder god son had the audacity to attack me during the opening 30 minutes of this random map skirmish.The ludicrousness of this scenario, as mythical creatures of various origins trundle in over peaceful farmland to murder everyone in sight, was Mythology's strength over Ensemble's Age of Empires II: The Age of Kings when it was released in 2002. Mythology's colourful range of high-level fantasy creatures make the final act of any skirmish much more exciting than units of historical repute did in Age of Kings. Kraken trouble the seas, dragon-like nidhoggs circle the skies and hydra grow a head for every enemy they slay.Age of Mythology does feel antiquated, but it is still a lot of fun. It wasn't a notably innovative RTS at release, mostly built on '90s ideas, but it did take Ensemble's blend of Civ-style city management and more conventional military RTS ideas to its creative peak, as well as making the series fully 3D for the first time.The upgraded effects of the Extended Edition, most noticeably the shiny-looking water, help contemporise Mythology, but the character models are the strongest signs that this is a decade-old game. AI is a bit of an issue, too. On a moderate difficulty, the enemies attack predictably in medium-sized waves while rarely putting up an overwhelming defence of their own territories.I don't hold that against Mythology, though, because it is still cathartic to steamroll the AI on random maps. The online multiplayer, too, means you won't be short on smarter opponents, and it seems to be running well, even if the process of finding a game you can join feels a bit arduous.The Extended Edition isn't short on single-player content, either. Collected here are the Titans expansion and the shorter Golden Gift DLC campaign, in addition to the original's mammoth story mode.Each campaign level is prefaced by in-engine cutscenes of hilariously low production values. Voice acting sounds like the product of three almost-drunk friends being handed the keys to a recording studio for an afternoon. This shortfall is probably another sign of its age and the industry standard of the time, but otherwise I think this is one of the better RTS campaigns of its day in the variety of the mission structure.You rarely feel like you're doing the exact same thing twice, and the parameters can change from survival to deathmatches and surprise ambushes. The impressively in-depth Scenario Editor helps to extend the singleplayer's lifespan, and with Workshop support, there's no fear of running dry of stuff to do.Age of Mythology still has a lot of value beyond nostalgia.This isn't a total remake, so don't go in expecting one. The Extended Edition is still a really well-paced and entertaining RTS, one that revels in over-the-top imagery and remains a one-off in subject matter within the oeuvre of the sadly departed Ensemble.

reviewText:
Short version - DO NOT BUY THIS GAME, even if you used to be a fan. The amateur developers have completely destabilized and destroyed the game.

Long version - I've never written a review before, but my recent experience with Age of Mythology has driven me to it.

Let me start out by saying that I've been playing this game since it originally came out and I've loved it the whole time. The campaign is incredible, the graphics are great for their time, and the strategy gameplay is the best I've ever seen. It's rare not to get bored of a game after playing it for 14 years, and I'd go as far as saying that AOM is my favourite game of all time.

The old AOM that is... Recently a set of wannabe developers have released DLC that is absolute crap, or at least that's what I've read in reviews, which is why I haven't bought the DLC. I figured I just wouldn't buy it and continue to enjoy the same game that I've enjoyed for years.

Of course, the old AOM had some bugs, but they were minor and the game was stable over all. Everything was fine until the fascist developers of this new DLC started screwing around with the original game! They've removed some technologies and units and added new ones, they've reskinned some things (and did a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ job), and they've introduced a ton of bugs to the gameplay. For example, god powers show up in the area for researching upgrades when you click on buildings like the wall and temple, technologies that you research show up in the wrong buildings or not at all, and when you drag to select units, the bottom area of the screen which shows who and what you selected either shows the wrong number of units, the wrong units, or nothing at all.

I paid to get the original Age of Mythology and the Steam version worked fine before, but the bugs these ameteurs introduced have turned the game into a steaming pile of you-know-what. If you want to add units and other new content, that's fine. Release it as a mod so that when people install it and it completely destroys the game, it's their fault they ruined it and not yours.

To summarise, even if you are a fan of the old AOM, don't buy this game, because sadly it's not the game you played back in the day. I really hope the developers get their ♥♥♥♥ together and stop ruining this classic.

reviewText:
I was a bit hesitant to buy this game. It has quite a BIG pricetag, especially keeping in mind that it's a 2002 game. A few months after release a sale came, I took a deep breath and bought the game.

I have to admit I was quite surprised and astonished. Despite all the bad critiques the remake is getting the game works like a charm. The visuals are beautiful, the gameplay is fluid and bug free. Even though there are known performance-eaters like SSAO and FXAA/BLOOM added to the game Age of Mythology still runs like what you'd expect from a 2002 game, except with better graphics. I'd put it between AOE HD (which looks horrid in my opinion, despite the HD" tag) and AOE III.

However the looks aren't everything.

Gameplay-wise (surprisingly) it's very much like the Age of Empires games
date: you can plow through several campaigns which mainly consists of gathering supplies
hoursPlayed: fending off smaller enemy attacks
voteText:
garrisoning a huge army and then defeating the enemy. It's a bit like Civilization on a more smaller "local" scale.

However the main difference from the Age of Empires games is the addition of:

- Epic Gods
- Magic powers
- Kickass monsters

To keep a long story short I think the developers really added extra "oomph" to an old classic spicing it up enough to be appealing even after 12 years. It's really up to you if you think the price-tag (which I admit is quite thick) is justifiable or you'll wait for it to go on a sale like I did.

Right after I bought this game I played four hours straight without even noticing the time. I think that's enough recommendation

reviewText:
Age of Mythology is Real Time Strategy game that has managed to achieve the rare aspect of balance in its gameplay. Picking and sticking to an 'overpowered god' from the start is not really possible, as gods are very much rock-paper-scissors with each other. You can pick a certain god that counters the Norse (Gaia, for example) which would be destroyed by the Greek. You do get the feeling as you go along that certain Gods have better abilities than others, although I feel this is largely down to personal perference. Loki for example, has the ability for his Hersirs to randomly spawn Myth units into the battle, which maybe considered 'OP' by those who are in a militaristic war against them. BUT, Hersirs are very weak to arrows. Gather a few archers and you're back in the game. But then they can build calvary. But then you can build spearmen, and it continues.

In terms of units, there isn't that much variety however it is not necessarily the units that you pick, but how you build the groups. When playing as the Greeks, two horseman, two archers and two infantry will survive longer than six archers.

I played this game many years ago and am happy to see it make a HD relaunch, however honestly there really isn't much difference. My main 'pet peeve' with this game is the online play which, to be brutally honest, frustrates me to no end. There are three aspects which irritate me, those being;
1) Sync errors. You can be 40 minutes into a game and you will suddenly get a pop up saying 'Saving: Sync Error' which is an 'oh ****' moment. Your 40 minutes is now worthless, as you will now be back at the Main Menu screen. What a waste of time. They offer no explanation, no 'just kick the out-synced player', EVERYONE is put back to the Main Menu with nothing to show for the last 40 minutes. Oh, and did I mention that some players use programs to force sync errors if they are losing? Yeah.
2) There's no option to vote-kick players midgame. The only option you have to kick a player is when they're about to disconnect, at which point the ENTIRE game comes to a halt for 30 seconds while you all vote. The voting, by the way, is pointless. Regardless of which option you pick (Continue or Wait) you will be forced to wait the full 30 seconds, even if the vote in unanimous.
3) The program itself. The program itself can randomly just shut down. You can be destroying the entire map and then your game will just suddenly shut down with no warning as if you've pressed Alt + F4.

Besides the above GLARING technical errors that I am in absolute disbelief haven't been fixed after x years since the game's release, the gameplay is actually very good. This is one of the most played, soon to be the most played game in my library. I would recommend, but I wish they'd sort out the gaping holes in their ship.

reviewText:
Major multiplayer lag across all games on official day of release. I expected at least some testing within the long 2-month lapse of the early copies already being handed out. reviewText:
FOR THE RECORD; Most of the negative reviews on the game aren't due to the actual mechanics and gameplay, but more to do with the terrible pricing, and the poor online netcode. If you're wanting to buy this game, DON'T BUY IT ON STEAM. Or at least wait until it's on a massive discount. Or better yet, buy a retail copy. That's the short version.

Now, about the game.
It's Age of Mythology. Which means it's a classic. Nuff said. The campaign is still amazing and holds up very well. The extended edition includes the Titans expansion which includes the Atlantean race, and the patched in content 'The Golden Gift' campaign. It's important to remember however that the campaign is also there to get you acquainted with the multiplayer mechanics.

The multiplayer is ok, but the Netcode is wack. Lag is inevitable, and the only people who play the MP now are either vets from the original retail version who will wreck your sh**, or the odd random. My advice.
Buy the game for the excellent singleplayer, and maybe jump online with a friend and get to grips with the unit intricacies, then have a go.

PRO's:
•	HD textures (not really noticeable)
•	Excellent campaigns
•	Solid balancing
•	Classic

Con's:
•	Dev's have abandoned the game. Horrific follow on development
•	Multiple glitiches in MP. Also crashes sometimes
•	AI is stupid as hell
•	Insane asking price


Conclusion: In my opinion, at this time the game isn't worth the Steam asking price. If you're willing to pay however, you'll have access to 3 campaigns, an editor, MP with all races, and skirmishes. All with a few HD textures.

If you're not short of a few quid, you could do a lot worse than this. Pick it up if you want to try out more RTS outside of StarCraft.

reviewText:
Age of Mythology was one of the few gems that dominated my childhood, I have many fond memories of throwing hours of my life into the hundreds of amazing maps that players designed shortly after release including The Settlers and Cat and Mouse. Despite being quite pricey for an old game I think it's worth every penny for one of the gems of the RTS genre.

The Extended Edition comes with some fantastic upgrades including full Steam Support and upgrades to the interface and textures of the game. I've been waiting a long time for this and I'm so happy this masterpiece is on Steam now.

Pros

+ Improved textures & Interface.
+ Solid mod support
+ Steamworks integration

Cons

- Suffers from the same network and desync problems that the original did.

Verdict 9/10

reviewText: Broken game, runs worse than the non-steam version; the MMR system is completely broken and people just desyncs right before they lose so you wont get any rating. The graphics are the same as the classic game, except they often glitch out. The units pathfinding is unbelievably ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and they will often get stuck in normally uncrossable terrain. reviewText:
When I saw the AoM:Extended Edition, it seemed like the perfect solution. We've played the game for years, but three CD's later, it was time to get another one. And I was tired of buying plastic media to play a game I paid for.

Steam's digital download seemed perfect. And then we actually tried playing the game.

Ensemble Studios should be (and probably is) ashamed to be associated with tis product. The refresh rate is pretty near 5 frames per second, despite my machine running brand new high-detail 3D games at 60 fps. The multiplayer data connection is so slow it's unplayable.

This was a complete and utter waste of money. Can't un-recommend this game enough. Just don't buy it.

reviewText: An HD remake of the original game, the spiritual sequel to Age of empires that's more about skirmishes between heroes and monsters than it is about setpiece armies and ancient kingdoms. The game takes large departures from the Empire serie,s but stays familiar enough to be recognizeable to an outsider. The game is fantastic, and although the mythos is bigger, the scale is a bit smaller: Military units always take multiple population, restricting your army size.\n\nNothing here will win you over if you disliked the game already, but if you were a fan then, you'll be a fan now. That said: Thirty dollars is pretty steep. I would wait for a sale.

reviewText:
Hey guys,

As most of those who bought this game, I just loved it as a kid. So I was so excited, I bought the 4-player pack for it when EE came out. But, this is the problem that hinders it:

Multiplayer is unplayable. It gets huge delay kinda lag (desync) and you just can't play with friends. There is literrally no reason to pick this up over it's older versions, as those can at least be played online with some programm like voobly. But this, this is just impossible.

Don't buy it, you will regret it.

All those guys recommending it just haven't tried multiplayer or don't care, but multiplayer would be the only reason to buy this, as the graphics are pretty much the same.

reviewText: Great game that is let down by its optimization and lack of modern day standards. Locked 100% GPU usage (even in the menu?!) on a 970 in a game that looks 10 years old...really? The multiplayer experience is horrific too, lags and disconnects that require you to restart your game almost every match. UI is the same as the 2002 version and there is no steam integration, there is just soooo much to complain about, such a loss of opportunity to revive such a great game. I feel sorry for the people that find £30 games expensive, I would be really angry if I needed that money after buying this game. New troops and gods are cool though, pretty much the only positives.

reviewText:
This is a great game. I've spent hours playing it and have enjoyed it for years. But, this Extended Edition is a piece of garbage. The game is completely glitched. One of the more innocuous glithces occurs when you click on, say a tree, and drag toward a unit the game will think you clicked on and are commanding the tree; thankfully though the commands will be of the unit, not of the tree. Then, there are the abominable graphical glitches which can, at times, make the game unplayable necessitating a reset. At times the map won't load. These glitches first showed up months ago, it seems the Microsoft Studios are trying their best to make their intent of milking the Age of Mythology till it's lying motionless sprawled across dead grass as obvious as they possibly could.

The most apt description of this version is schizophrenic. It will reset in the middle of a game, the entire game will close, the graphics will disintigrate, and all other assortments of frustrations. If anyone is curious my computer can handle games with superior graphics with no issue, the problem is rooted in the version of this game itself.

If you want to play this game then buy an old version of it on CD. This version isn't even worth the $4.99 that it'll occasionally be sold for let alone the regular 29.99; it leads to too many irritations. After all, the improved graphics" are meaningless when the entire Christ forsaken game can't handle them to the point where it glitches to Hell!"

reviewText:
Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is an RTS that has in my opinion stood the test of time.  First and foremost this game is related almost directly to the Age of Empires collection. The big difference is the injection of Mythology and Gods instead of historical civilizations like in Age of Empires. A few different things have been changed but you will see about the same formulas being practiced.

When I first started playing this game it was almost ten years ago. I had very slow internet but thankfully found this solid game on disk. I was amazed with the quality and the single player replayability. One of my favorite things is the simple and fun editor where you can make your own maps or your own challenges. I would mostly roleplay in which I would make up different battles and very own campaign. It was very satisfying when I could put time into my own ideas.

I have always liked the resource race in this game as well where you start by hunting then move up to farming or knowing when to get that next woodcutting or mining upgrade. Managing your economy with your military plays a very large part too. There are many small things in this game that make it feel very well done, as an example when your units are upgraded it updates the armor and weapon textures. Little things like that have always appealed to me while playing because it makes me feel like the developers really cared about this game. I read about how the developers argued for days over the god powers to make sure they were balanced. I believe that's called making a good game to were you care so much about the fairness you push yourself and others that hard.

Skybox is another story. I enjoy the fact steamworks is now into the game and instant modifications can be applied that enhance the way I play the game but they have done an ok" job. The price is a little to much for a game that is this old. Right now is a sale for around $7 and I would recommend you buy it at a time like this but $30 on the other hand is just too much when the disk has been in the bargin bin for half a decade. I could go on about the desync issues but in the end I will recommend this game in its current state.

Honestly I am just really happy this is on Steam. I have met so many of die hard fans that I would have never met playing offline so very long ago. It really makes me glad that the community still cares and likes to have a good time with this awesome relic.

Thanks for reading."

It is still a blast to play and the gameplay hasn't aged a bit.

reviewText: I liken these recent updated Ensemble/Microsoft classics to buying a Ferrari full of puppies and pizza, they're that much fun. Take some of the best games from our gaming history, update them to work well on modern machines including the multiplayer components, then blow them out with a giant list of modern features like cloud save, achievements, trading cards, workshop, stats and on and on, sell them for a reasonable price and here we are, with a game that I will play until the end of my days.\n\nYou don't get nearly as many wide-eyed blissful moments with gaming or with most other things in your adult years compared to your childhood, but that's exactly how I felt 30 minutes into playing this updated version, like a kid on Christmas morning. While I may seem a little over the top in my effusive praise, look here; Ensemble is my favorite developer of all time, Age of Empires II and Age of Mythology are among my favorite games of all time, and these updated versions of those games tick every box I need them to tick and then some. This is pure gaming perfection as far as I'm concerned.

reviewText:
========================================

Vince Rowe ReviewsSaving the Industry one Game at a Time!

[YouTube Link]   [Curation Link]

========================================


Age of Mythology is one of the classic Real-Time Strategy games now released on Steam with a High-Definition make-over and a few tweaks here and there.

Pros:+ Adequate Graphics
+ Easy to Learn
+ A lot to Master
+ Lots of Units (Air, Water and Land)
+ Different Civilisations (4 lots of 3)
+ Civilisations have very different play styles
+ Lots of different Civilisation specific units with their own unique specials
+ Fast Gameplay
+ UI is easy to understand and learn
+ Stalemate Breakers (Titans)
+ Balanced Gameplay (Each Civilisation has good and bad points ranging from economy to combat)
+ Greater focus on Economy
+ Randomly Generated Maps/Terrain
+ Bots with varying difficulties and play-styles
+ Small Details such as Day/Night cycles
+ Great to play with others
+ Runs perfectly on my machine (Sub-Par PC)
+ Massive Re-playability
+ Achievements and Trading Cards

Cons:- Graphics could be better
- Far too pricey for an old game (I'd get it on a sale if I were you)
- Multiplayer is a bit buggy at times
- Almost Identical to the old game with no changes
- Online is relatively dead (Apart from the ~30 consistent players)


I like it; I really like it in fact! I was genuinely surprised about how much I actually enjoy this game and how much I will play of this for the days to come.


My Personal Experience:
Before I get into all of this, I should probably tell you that most of this pros and cons are compared to Age of Empires 2 HD which me and friends used to play before we got this game. After playing Age of Empires 2 HD for ages my mate decided to get us all a 4-pack and subject him further into his completely unnecessary debt that he had collected - regardless he made a good choice - Free Gayumes!

Age of Mythology - unlike Age of Empires 2 HD - is very driving, it actually has points of interest that you need to focus on, you're limited to 115 population after building all of your houses and in order to raise it you must then start making Town Centres on top of the Settlements that are strategically placed around the map. At first we were 'iffy' about these but after playing for about 20 minutes we realised they made the game far better than Age of Empires 2 HD was. The thing is, Age of Empires 2 HD isn't very driving, it's quite slow paced and the only real strategies are to either rush them early or build your economy up and attack them in one final push; basically you only really have one properly battle in Age of Empires HD but Age of Mythology on the other hand - you'll have many. You'll find yourself fighting over these Settlements purely for the fact that they give you 15 (+3 from an upgrade) which is enough to turn the entire game into your advantage. This allows for a snowballing effect which feels extremely fresh after playing Age of Empires 2 HD for so long. What I'm trying to say is that this game is better than Age of Empires 2 HD!

The Civilisations though - these are fun! You've got 4 main groups of Civilisations; Greek, Egyptian, Norse and Atlantean. Each of these have 3 counter-parts to them but there's no real point in me going into those, they have some differences but those in the same sub-groups are very similar to each other. The main point are the Gods though, each Civilisation has a total of 9 different gods which you have to choose from in tiers unlocking you God specific creatures such as Hydras and Manticores (Greek Myth Units - Myth are basically a type of Unit). This just makes up for so much customisations from your type of early-game economy build, to the overall God build you pick from, to the creatures you decide to fight with, to the buildings you decide to build, to the upgrades you decide to pick first, the list goes on and on - no doubt there's meta-builds somewhere though if you're that kind of person.

Like I said, the graphics are nice but there's no excuse for them not being better, this is 2015 and these graphics don't look any near that! When you compare it to the original is extraordinary but when you compare to other RTS games of this time... Oh wait... There are none...
It still looks pretty good none-the-less though and you'll be spending most of your time zoomed out anyway to see what the hell is going on anyway so that's why I don't really see this as that much of a problem.

I've said all I really want to say about this game, I like it; I really like it in fact! I was genuinely surprised about how much I actually enjoy this game and how much I will play of this in the future.

Link to my Curations.

reviewText:
I think the devs made a mistake in emphasizing the shiny new graphics and features, because yes, they look stunning compared to the older version, but unfortunately I believe many people have gotten the impression that that's the only thing they're getting for their thirty bucks.

I would honestly buy this game on steam without any additions for the same price. The better graphics can disappear for all I care, because what this re-release truly means is the return of multiplayer, a bigger, more active community, and devs that actually listen and actively improve the game. In my opinion, that is what I am buying, and I am not disappointed with the results.

I would definitely recommend this to anyone whether old or new, to relive the experience or see it for the first time. :)

reviewText: EXACTLY the same as the original mythology with extremely, extremely minor detail differences that aren't noticable whatsoever. The graphics are still as bad as they used to be, the glitches haven't been fixed or even touched on, the AI hasn't been improved (so you still have the issue of 50% of your ally's/enemies freezing and doing nothing all match) and it genuinely is NOT extended by any definition. The story is the same, the gameplay is the same, the night/day cycle DOESN'T WORK and despite the massive nolstagic trip out it still has nothing good going for it. I'd consider this a waste of money. There are other games that are much better and there are other developers who don't mislead you who also do genuinely good work, save your money for yourself or for people who deserve it.
voteText: 12 of 20 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Having grown up with this game (and lost my original CD) it was absolutely fantastic to see it available on Steam. However I was quite baffled when I saw the game's price tag; to demand 27,99€ for a game that is more than a decade old is absurd, saying it is a HD remake does not even justify the price - graphics are the same as it was back in 2002, but with dynamic shadows and a day/night cycle.

If you didn't play Age of Mythology back when it was released I wholeheartedly recommend it as the game features:
Great campaign storyline.
Well made characters.
Decent balanced factions.
An interesting history menu where you can read about the lore of individual units.
Beautiful background music.
To this day, I still consider Age of Mythology to be one of the most successful RTS games ever made and to play it again after 12 years really gives me a sense of nostalgia, but if want to buy it I would suggest looking elsewhere as a HD remake does not justify a 27,99€ price tag.

reviewText:
A good classic RTS game with nice thematics, story, gameplay. Comes with the Titans expansion, which adds up to the game. Also has some improved details in the graphics, compared to the original version.

Has a great atmosphere, varied and balanced factions, lots of different units, and a great, massive campaign. There's a friends-only and a global ranked system for multiplayer mode (btw filter by ping before picking your games, since it's an international level).

Had several bugs since it came out and some laggy features, but it's noticeable that the support team is working on it, many were fixed. I thought it would be a little cheaper, but although it's a bit expensive, it's totally worth it.

reviewText:
Summary - The Chinese expansion is rushed, copy-pasted from existing things, and glitchy. The people who profit from this are not the ones who made the original Age of Mythology.

Icons for Chinese buildings are re-used existing ones.

Chinese god powers and soldiers are like copies of existing ones, just changed a little bit. For example, the chinese monk is the egyptian priest with a different model, texture, icon and description, and instead of converting animals he converts enemies. He waves his arms and makes the exact same chant, and the cursor turns into an Egyprian Ankh when you mouse-over enemies.

Incorrect descriptions - The two Chinese heroes we start with are given Arkantos's description of special powers.

Poor story-telling - Unlike the original campaign, the beginning of the Chinese campaign has very little story-telling. You are not introduced to the gods, and you just start already in the second age. We only have a brief introduction to the heroes.
At the beginning of the campaign...
/(SPOILER)\nThe heroes have to travel across China because when they realise there's evil afoot, a random peasant tells them to cross china, and so they do with no questions asked.
\(SPOILER)/

Graphic glitches on my new-ish computer - You can see flames if the ground is behind them, but not if the sky if behind them. When placing walls. the wall segment that is behind another is drawn in front of what is actually in front of it.

Glitched first scenario in the Chinese campaign - You start in the Second age, but if you restart you are in the first age.

It runs slowly.

You can drag a box to select four soldiers and it will tell you you've selected only two, or the bamboo tree" nearby.

My fortified wall upgraded to an earthen wall.

I got a steam card of Thor with a really bad picture on it
date: with the description "The Norse god of lightning". Thor is the god of thunder
recommended: not lightning. Loki is the god of lightning.\n\nThis is my review after only getting to the second scenario in the Chinese campaign

reviewText: Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is a fun RTS game that allows you to play as different ancient gods and use their different abilities to wipe out your enemies. If you're a super competitive gamer and love trying a bunch of various strategies I would totally recommend this game, this is for you. I haven't played the other Age of Mythology games, so I can't say how accurate this one is, however this was recommended to me by a friend who says it's very accurate. Take that as a third party source, though.\nThis is by no means a bad game, and it excels in what it does. It provides a challenging RTS experience that you can enjoy with friends or on your own. The problem for me comes from the game being a tad too competitive. This might not be a problem for you, and it might actually be a good thing. If that's the case you should get this game, probably when it's on sale. If you share the same opinion as me in this area in that you would rather spend your time goofing off than strategising and micromanaging resources, I would say no, you'd be better off spending your money on something else. That's just me, and I understand a lot of people feel otherwise, but for people like me I have to say no, I don't recommend it.

reviewText:
As far as the game itself is concerned, it's simply an amazing and beloved classic.
However, most people would want to purchase it when it's on sale, due to the fact that it's quite overpriced.
All in all, I am inclined to believe that Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is a very enjoyable game and may offer endless hours of entertainment to both longtime RTS fans and newcomers to the genre and/or franchise.

Notable features and additions to the old game, for those who are interested in further info:
Updated graphics and textures! Now suitable for higher (e.g. HD) resolutions!Long awaited bugfixes and balance changes!Trading cards!Achievements!Steam Workshop for all kinds of mods (easy to install and upload mods)!

reviewText: Compelling storyline, diversity in player races/classes, and well thought-out map/level design makes this game the best in the franchise. I just finished playing all three, and I can't get over how they overlooked the idea of having 3 distinct player races have separate strengths and weaknesses that accomodate most playstyles to an RTS. Of course, its easy" campaign option makes the campaign a rewarding experience as you play through all three classes in 48 scenarios. I haven't really dug into the multiplayer yet
date: but if I did I would feel more than prepared after such an engaging campaign.\n\nIf you were thinking about getting into franchises or RTS in general

reviewText: This has got to be one of my all time favorite games, an easy top 10 series (and I have been gaming for about 20 years +).  I have been playing this sinec the beta released!  Yes, that many years ago.  I still have my original discs for them and expansion.  Why buy this again on Steam!?  Because its ♥♥♥♥ing amazing and I believe in supporting the companies you like.  Considering I have gotten several thousand hours of fun play time out of this, yes, they earned another sale from me.  So many different ways you can go and play with friends.  Titan challenges are fun as well.  One of my all time best was a rush with Odin winning in 10 minutes (killing all units and buildings), and making a hard mode CPU forfit in 8.  Not saying I am the worlds best, but this is such a great classic.  9/10 (no game is perfect).

Age of Mythology: Tales of the Dragon

--> Prós: (5%)

reviewText: Age Of Mythology is one of the best Real Time Strategy games ever made. It is unrivaled in depth and imagination. The playability of the game is endless. The campaign in Single Player may seem short for some people who like single player mode, but awaiting you and everyone is a massive base of user created scenarios and creations. In multiplayer this games is at it's best when it works. The new P2P style lobby system seems a little more unstable that the ESO system used previously. This game is a keeper, everyone who has it loves it.

reviewText:
Just as good as I remember.

Age of Mythology kept me busy for many hours when it first released in 2002 and it seems like it will do so now as well.

If there's anything wrong with this game the only thing I can mention is how Vsync doesn't function in Multiplayer. There hasn't been any other technical trouble that I have ran into. Running this on my 7 year old rig just fine.

So what is Age of Mythology?If you've ever played any of the Age of Empires games you'll know what you're getting into. Age of Mythology adds mythical creatures as units and adds (limited use) god powers from those gods who you choose to worship.

Pros:
+ Classic gameplay intact
+ Readily includes The Titans expansion and Golden Gift extra
+ New visual updates work
+ Steam workshop
+ Online interface and scenario sharing simple
+ Developers keen to update
+ New Tale of the Dragon expansion coming over a decade later
+ Prostagma!

Cons:
- Multiplayer servers regularly don't display properlly
- Online lag

reviewText: While for most re-releases, the publishers at least went through the trouble of giving the games a marginal graphical update, this is not the case for AoM. The Extended Edition looks 1-to-1 exactly the same as the original. Everything uses textures that look like we are still playing on 640x480 screens instead of 3840x2160. In fact, despite the 3D graphics of this game, the HD version of Age of Empires II looks vastly superior. This is shameless money grab with no work done whatsoever.

reviewText: Ensebmle made the first games I ever played, and I still find them enjoyable now. While Skybox with AoM: EE doesnt really bring anything new to the table, it is still an incredibly fun game. The community got a much needed shot in the arm, and despite what many say, you can find people to play with if you are persistent enough. I am not sure if it is entirely worth the asking price, but if this gem ever goes on sale, pick it up, even if only for the campaign. This game has given me 100s of hours of enjoyment in its day, and I am sure that it will continue to provide many more with this new release.

to reach back to the nostalgia of setting up my first pc just to play this game after i saw a relative playing it and got dazzled

it's actually hard to find something you don't like in this game it reaches us to a time when more effort and imagination was put in making video games you have to think ensamble studios made this game to the amusement of the gamers as their primary target not their wallets

reviewText: As a kid I loved Age of Mythology and played hundreds of hours. Seeing this expansion has really been a knife in the back of the game I once loved so much. Why are units able to be garisonned in buildings if the rally point is set to them??? The answer a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ effort from the game developers who not only managed to ruin the new content but also the existing game. . . Thanks!

reviewText:
The first time I launched this game it actually worked fine. However, last night it came time to download an update to it... 6.0MB/6.0 ... DISK READ ERROR ... 121.0MB/121.0MB ... DISK READ ERROR ... An hour later the same ♥♥♥♥ing thing ... I defragmented my harddrive, cleaned my system with ccleaner and did an error check to my harddrive, and after a couple of more hours... NOPE! 0 bytes network usage, 0 bytes disk usage, 100 % completion of the update and... DISK READ ERROR!!! GRRRRRRRRRR!!!!!!!! What the ♥♥♥♥! I've never encountered anything like this before! Why doesn't it let me download an update to it? Why does my PC let me surf the net, chat and write this review even though the steam client doesn't let me complete the download of an important update! If you still consider buying this game after reading this review, you're a ♥♥♥♥ing idiot! I see if I can get a refund for it...

EDIT: Wait! What! What! It ACTUALLY, finally managed to download the update after, like, 5-6 hours (and the verification of the game files). I might keep the game afterall (too much trouble trying to get a refund right now), but the review stays negative...
All of this is just so sad, Age of Mythology is a really great game as long as it runs and doesn't crash or anything... ♥♥♥♥ing bugs! Made me think my harddrive was going to fail...

reviewText:
UPDATE: I saw people complaining about a terrible glitch with the Chinese factions of everything suddenly being destroyed when the scenario begins and losing immediately because of it. At first I didn't have that problem, I was even able to play a few levels of the Chinese storymode, NOW IT'S DOING IT FOR NOT JUST THE STORYMODE BUT NOW FOR EVERY FACTION AND EVERY RANDOM MAP I TRY TO PLAY!!! WTF!!

Let me be clear that I love Age of Empires. It's the best real time strategy game of all time, but compared to earlier entries like Age of Empires 2, AoMythology feels like it's lacking. The growth and movements are a lot slower than I remember them to be, and despite the game being remastered with better graphics of the environment and buildings they are still really poor in terms of units (they're basically a few crude shapes with arms). the system of heroes and myth units put a difficult wrench into the mix of unit advantages, and it seems no matter how much you upgrade they die very quickly unless you have an overwhelming force. The buildings compared to AoE2 are also much weaker. Whereas in AoE2 castles and towers could protect you from all sorts of forces, the defenses in Age of Mythology are practically made of cardboard. It almost makes artillery pointless because so long as you're willing to lose a couple of cheap units you can stab whole fortresses to death in a matter of moments, something you and the enemy could rarely do in Age of Empires 2.

There is one thing Age of Mythology has that is better than other titles and that's the learning element. It won't teach much history, but when you click on unit icons it opens up a short description of the unit's stories in mythology for myth units or if it's a human unit it will have a small explanation of that unit's weapons or place in ancient history. Even clicking on a wild animal will bring up it's scientific name and other facts about it. For learning purposes, this is the best part of the game.

Something I loved about Mythology is that it had much better and much crazier cheatcodes. I'll never forget the glory that is WUV WOO and O CANADA which spawn a flying purple hippo and a superhero bear with the Canadaian flag on it's back. Yet for some reason, I can't get any of them to work anymore. That's reall disappointing for me because those cheats were amazing.

All in all, I bought this game for the nostalgia and the new Chinese faction dlc, but feel it was not worth buying again. I much more recommend Age of Empires 2 because it is faster paced, more balanced, slightly cheaper, and has a lot more cultures to choose from.

reviewText:
I was excited when i saw that this game was getting an HD remake for the modern day of PC Gaming. I remember play this AoM with my friend at his house since i didn't own the game. Of course i loved it so much i bought my own copy and installed it on my computer. I spent hours playing this game, day and night i would play. So naturally, when i saw that this game was being released on steam with an texture update, i was excited! And after playing this game for 52 hours, i thought i give me take on the game.

When you first load up the game, the game is different from the start, Having used a moving background behind a new menu layout gave it the feel of a new game, even though it wasn't. I loved the feel of the new menu (although some people didn't, as their a mod in the workshop for the old one, i didn't see a problem with the new one). and the world in the background was an awesome idea.

Now as i said before, it did recieve an texture update, and yes it looks completely better then the old game, it still has the old game feel to it. They achieve the new look while keeping the way the orginal AoM looks and feels. I'll admit, when i first heard of AoM: EE i was thinking they overhauled the graphics on it and have the characters working mouths! Sadly, they didn't, but that doesn't mean they didn't update the game. The water and land textures (Greek, Norse etc.) have all been updated.

Gameplay was as just much fun as it was when i was a kid. Building huge armies and storming the Gates of Troy was just as exciting as i remember it being. Of course not every game is perfect, at some points, when moving an army they would get stuck or move in a direction i didn't tell them too. When this happend, i would have  to kill some people or make the army smaller (by killing them) so the rest of the army could move, then i would have to rebuild the lost men and gather then up for battle. Yet, this was the only real problem i encounter in the game. With the edition of steam groups to the game, any bugs or glitches that come up and brough to the developer and are fixed quickly. Thats right, the developer actually cares what the people say and fix the problems that are bothering their fans!

The campaign in this game consist of three storys. Fall of the Trident follows Arkantos jouney to appease the God Posiden,  Even if it means storming the Gates of Troy, or chasing his villian across the world! The campaign that comes from the Titan expansion follows Kastor, Arkantos son, as he struggles to lead his people following the events of the first campaign. A campaign i can't recall if it was in AoM is the Golden Boar. This campaign follows two dwarves on their wacky adventure to retrieve their golden boar! (It's not really wacky but it has its funny moments). Nothing new in the story section, the game keeps true to the old campaign leaving it how it was.

With the steam groups added also comes Steam Workshop. Adding this to the game makes the content of this game seem limitless now. Adding mods to the game can change your gameplay (either with new maps or new scenarios etc). Allowing mods to this game just makes it even better to play by adding more hours of gameplay.

Overall, the game was great! I missed playing this game and now that i have it on Steam (making it easier to keep track off, i lose disk a lot) just makes it so much better. For my first review i give the game a 9/10. I gave it a 9 for great gameplay (even if its nothing new from the old game), fresh new textures (which look great!), the story was awesome too ,and only one glitch that i could find. And most importantly, keeping the feel and enjoyment of what the AoM had. Extented Editions of games sometimes lose what the original game brought, and AoM: EE kept that while improving the game. So if you're an old fan or a newcomer, AoM: EE is the perfect RTS for you!
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game, it is one of my comfort games, and the best $20 dollars my parents spent on me, back in 2006. I have played for hours and hours.
Played the whole story through and through at least four times.
I love this, and cannot speak highly enough of it.

I've always played as an Egyptian, my favorite, and also my strength.
A great story, campaign engrossing.

The only thing I will say, is as this is a remastering, it does have a few glitches here and there, but nothing that hinders the game play.
You cannot easily build a map, like you could in the disk version.
But, life goes on.
I am just so happy to play this game again!

Buy it, and I hope we'll do battle someday!

Single player: RECOMMENDED!

No the graphics aren't modern. This is a classic game. One I happened to have missed. And it is awesome good fun, if you like this genre and/or the mythology theme.

AoM can be pretty challenging, too. I can't imagine playing on the highest difficulty atm. Which means there is someone out there that will LOVE this game for the challenge that would offer.

LAN/multiplayer: NOT RECOMMENDED!

OMFG WHYEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE?! /emocide! /homocide!! /genociduhduhduhduh!!! ... /flop!!!1 Yea, it *is* that bad.  Still. Yes. Still that bad. If they haven't fixed it yet, I seriously question if they will fix this ever. Yes, that is sad, since the multiplayer aspect is the whole reason for the extended edition reissue.

Any game starts off okay, but as soon as you guys begin to progress at all the game begins to hang/stutter a bit, then it hangs like crazy for 30 seconds at a time and eventually someone will just get booted altogether, which completely ruins the game.

It does not matter if you have a decent (or better) gaming rig and a good internet connection set up for a multi-gamer household. I don't know what they messed up, but they did mess something up badly and it makes LAN unplayable. I assume multiplayer (online) would be even worse since I can't even play duo with someone on LAN.

reviewText:
The game has always been full of bugs, but now they've taken it to a new level!

The latest release can't hold an online game reliably.  I'm seeing 80%+ of my games end with a sync error now!  It just quits and its tough luck.  That on its own is enough to make this game pointless.

This is on top of all the other bugs that already existed within the game (too many to mention).

They also have blocked off parts of the game previously accessible, like the nomad map now requires you buy the expansion.  Not only that but the name gods are rather unbalanced, meaning the only way to win is to buy the expansion to get the more powerful gods.

Totally awful poorly tested product.  Do not buy this game they're a rip off.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Masterpiece.
Age of Mythology was the first game I ever played seriously. The interesting and diverse gameplay, the deceptively complex game mechanics, and the lovely graphics for the era all make for a game that is thrilling and incredibly fun to play.

This game has a certain charm about it; perhaps because of my experiences playing this game. The graphics may not be those of Fallout 4, The Witcher, or other such Triple-A Titles, but the gamemplay more than makes up for this.
A lot of Age of Mythology's fun and diverse gameplay comes from its roster of incredibly diverse pantheons, and within those different gods that have different specialties. No two matches are the same, and playing with friends is incredibly fun.

Overall, Age of Mythology was a major part of my childhood and I enjoy it to death. I could not recommend this game more, and it holds a special place in my heart.

reviewText: As a kid, this was the first game I ever played. I would spend hours at a time playing it. When I saw that it was up on Steam, I was thrilled. I immediately bought it. The community is fairly small, but is close knit, and great maps are coming from the original AoM title back onto here. If you're on the fence about this game, take my word for it and by it. There are still some issues, but those are minor and you can hop right back into the game. The campaign is one of the best I have ever played, and creating your own game type/map is one of the best things that a video game can offer. Not only that, but you can gain info about the civilization that you are playing as AND get info on units like the minotaur, cyclops, and fire giants, just name a few. And what's NOT great about destroying your enemy with a bunch of giants spewing fire and ice?

reviewText:
I've logged more time in AoM than probably any other game ever... except maybe Skyim.

This is the end-all-be-all of RTS for me.  I've played every AoE game, Warcraft 2 and 3, and countless hours of Starcraft 2.  Age of Mythology wins.

The races have drastic differences in appearance, economy, and combat function.  Combat is more economy focused than Starcraft and Warcraft.  If you've ever played an Age of Empires game than you have a basic understanding of what you're in for, but add way more variety in the races from square 1, add unique research abilities based on the gods you worship, and god powers that can drastically shift the battle at any second.

reviewText:
Played this game when it was first released and loved it. I think this was the game that got me into playing RTS's. Played lots of different ones over the years but this one has always remained a favourite. I often hoped (and still do) that AOM 2 might be in the making. So i was over the moon when i saw this was going to be re-released.....a chance for the Phoenix to rise from the ashes once again and burn my enemies to the ground.

If you haven't played this before don't expect an amazing graphical experience. The graphics have been improved, the sound aswell.....but the reason to play this is for the enjoyment. Its simple to pick up and play. However, experienced RTS gamers who haven't yet tried it, might find it too basic.

Still, it's a classic and deserves a place in the RTS hall of fame.

LAZER CROCS FTW

reviewText: I own AOE: Gold Edition and before that I owned the Titans Expansion + Regular game before I lost it. I would have clocked up at least 500 hours in this game in my time. In my opinion this game is superior to any Age of Empires game available
recommended:
this game is honestly superior to any RTS strategy game I've ever played.

It has every feature from all of the other "Age Of" games and more. Mythical units? ♥♥♥♥ yes. Fantastic campaigns? ♥♥♥♥ yes. Amazing map editor and scenario creator? ♥♥♥♥ yes. TITANS? ♥♥♥♥ yes! Heroes? ♥♥♥♥ yes. 4 different unique races? ♥♥♥♥ yes. A new resource? ♥♥♥♥ yes. I could go on for ♥♥♥♥ing ever but I won't because spoilers. (I'm too lazy.)

In my opinion
hoursPlayed: AOE2 is only more popular because it is simpler. This game has many
voteText:

I whole heartedly recommend this game. It is worth well over 30 dollars.
