reviewText: I have been enjoying this game for quite a long time. Bought the original edition in 2005 and a love affair began. This game is really one of the top RTS of all time with it's unique universe and time setting. The Ancient world has been never made before so nicely and I think several years after it's debut we can still say exactly the same. You have the stunning game modes, you have the outstanding editor, modding is pretty easy, just have a look at the biggets fan site (http://aom.heavengames.com/) where you can find plenty of help and of course the actual products of the hardworking modders.\n\nThe Extended Edition brang back one of the things that I missed for a while, the Multiplayer mode. ESO was shut down and the game lost it's playerbase a bit, but the revival is finely made and hopefully we are going to see many new faces and of course the old ones. :) Other pro is the fantastic graphic effects. I never imagined that this edition will look that good after I saw the press release pictures. I can only recommend getting it as it's a game that you cant miss before you die.

reviewText: I'm a AoM veteran, this is pretty much just a graphics overhaul with the DLC installed, squashed most bugs and with servers. Since ESO was disconnected by Microsoft  the classic AoM can only be played with gameranger, which odes not contains a very wide variety like it used to on the in-game matchmaking system.I did like this port and I didn't have any issues other than poor framerate (even though i can play most games on mid-high with 60 fps) and the fact that people aren't doing those fun multiplayer games anymore (like cyclops throwing minigame, minotaurus arena, rpg scenarios, tower defenses, which i miss a lot :'( )  I also feel like they could have made better improvements like adding community mods (rotate buildings, more maps, etc.) or added a new campaign or game mode, but it's okay cause it's got workshop plugged into it, which saves the time and effort of installing mods.  But anyway, i only bought it cause it was on sale, I wouldn't spend 30 dollars on this even though I love the classic game :/\n\nTL;DR: It's pretty much a graphics overhaul and bug squashing, buy it only if you miss playing ranked or if you like to play LAN with friends, it's not worth 30 dollars though.

reviewText:
For any of you young-in's wondering why Grandpa is playing this game. It's because back in my day this was great! AND IT STILL IS!

For anyone old enough to remember the glory days of Age of Empires, or playing Age of Mythology the first time around they will appreciate ever small update thrown into this game. It's not just a small upgrade to an already solid product, it's a vast improvement built upon a solid foundation.

All the old bugs that ruined the game have been squashed, the game itself comes bundled with the expansion and a host of new features. Still just as fun to learn this time around as it was then!

So if you are a bit cautious, watch some Let's Play videos or ask people that have it or remember the good old days. You won't go amiss with dropping money on this game. Hell, Zeus might even look kindly upon you.

reviewText:
Age of Mythology was the number one game of my childhood, so when I saw an upcoming remake, I directly bought it, no matter the high cost at the time.
After 40 hours of playing, I'm glad to say that the team of AoM:EE has done a great job of keeping the old atmosphere of the game by not changing much, however still making it better through the new functions and new graphics.
The huge plus the extended edition delivers is Steam Integration - Finally, we have a functioning community which does not only consist of AoMHeaven, but of a better developed Steam Community with all the Steam Features. The Workshop grants great accessibility to Mods and the recent Updates, the Ranking system, the events and the loads of achievements guarantee long-term playability.

The big question: Is it worth the money?
If you enjoy real-time strategy and haven't played Age of Mythology before, I would highly recommend buying AoM:EE. It is THE classic real-time strategy game, which is, in my eyes, even better than Age of Empires and the EE with all its features is pretty cheap for a brand new strategy game for you, comparing it to other strategy games on the market.

If you have already played AoM, I would not recommend buying it at its current price. It has many new features, but if you know the game already, it's just not worth the money.
Buy it, but wait for a major sale.

reviewText: It's the exact same game I played a decade ago, just... prettier.  There are some nice visual effects added, but the character models and all of the graphics are the same, and the cutscenes of a decade ago are laughable by modern standards.  That's not necessarily a bad thing, though.  It was a very good RTS a decade ago, and there's nothing wrong with updating the skin while leaving the bones of the game entirely intact.\n\nIf you're like me, and you've been dying to play this game again (now that it will work on a modern computer), definitely buy it.  In fact, I would recommend it to just about anyone who enjoys a good RTS.  Just maybe wait until the price comes down a bit.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Just a warning to the people who play COH, Men of War: Assault Squad, DOW, Wargame: Red Dragon, etc. This isn't any of those games by a long shot. Not just graphically, but in the way it works. The way you build your economy matters. It can be tedious at times, but managing the economy the right way to get your units out and be aggressive has some appeal.

The multiplayer somewhat good. The lobby is easy to navigate, and matches are quick to find. The games are RUINED by the TERRIBLE lag you get. Everything lags, and the more players you put in, the worse it gets. 1 v 1 has the game stuttering, 2 v 2 has the game going slo mo.

Get it if you want a deeper RTS game that is dated, but still good.

Pass if you want an action oriented RTS, with as little base building and economy as possible.

reviewText:
I played this game a lot when it first came out in 2002 and I was really excited to hear that an extended version would be released on Steam.

After the original eso servers went down, there was no longer an option to play this game in multiplyer without using GameRanger or Voobly (both good efforts but they are also lacking a lot of options). With the integration in Steam there is a working in-game multiplayer lobby again, which is by far the best addition to this game. The polished graphics are also a nice bonus compared to the original game.

At the moment some bugs still have to get fixed and some minor tweaks to the multiplayer lobby would be appreciated but I would definatly recommend this game to all strategy-fans, especially if you can pick it up during summer sales!

reviewText: This is a bit of a mixed bag here... Age of Mythology was one of the best, if not the best, real time strategy games of all time.  The expansion was incredible, and the extended edition adds some really cool stuff (the day/night cycle is beautiful!)  But to release a 12 year old game for $30 and not bother to fix bugs before releasing it?  The word scam comes to mind...  What possible explanation could there be for 'rushing' the re-release of a game from a dozen years ago?  If it were only Steam integration issues, it'd be less shameful, but things like memory leaks and texture issues should have fixed BEFORE charging anyone money for it.  I'd wait until they fix more bugs and it goes on sale for 75% off.  That said, if the thought of playing a modernized version of such a spectacular game is just too tempting to wait on, you won't be disappointed.  I haven't found the bugs to be too bad and the Steam Workshop is, as always, full of amazingness and growing quickly.

reviewText: I never played this game when it was released, I played it much later (2014) but enjoyed it a lot. I can see why people had been recommending it to me for years and telling me it was a classic. It's an old style strategy game like Age of Empires 1 and 2 except with a mythological theme, with Greek/Egyptian/Atlantaean Gods and legends and stuff. Your villagers harvest resources and build stuff, you recruit soldiers from your buildings and build watchtowers and walls and so on. It's kinda pointless me giving it a score because it's so old but if you're fond of strategy games from this era and you liked Age of Empires or games of that style then I'd definitely recommend it.

reviewText:
A conversation between me and Cydran about Age of Mythology: Extended Edition.


AA | Cydran: Was it as well remade as you expected?
AA | Cydran: or as you were hoping?
Veldar: Well.
Veldar: It's the same game, just with the expansion I never got, it feels dated, I can tell there are flaws and comming from C&C generals, a much faster game AoM feels very slow to start, getting your economy right is essential which is fine but I prefer the mirco of C&C to the marco of AoM, but the game still has a special place in my heart as the first game I remember asking for and it being my first PC title.
Veldar: I still love it though.
AA | Cydran: Very nice. I assume that means that new players going into the version of AoM on Steam might not enjoy it as much as they would if they played the game in the past?
Veldar: Well to make a judgement you have to put RTS into two piles:
Veldar: Mirco and Marco
Veldar: Micro is the faster games C&C generals and Warcraft 3, matchs should last 5 - 15 minutes.
Veldar: Where Macro, games like AoM, AoE 3 and SubCom are more about early economy and massing armies then pitting them against each other.
AA | Cydran: I see
Veldar: I prefer Micro so a Macro game feels slower to me, I still very much enjoy it and I'll play the ♥♥♥♥ out of it but I know that it's not the best RTS by any means.

reviewText:
Just a warning to the people who play COH, Men of War: Assault Squad, DOW, Wargame: Red Dragon, etc. This isn't any of those games by a long shot. Not just graphically, but in the way it works. The way you build your economy matters. It can be tedious at times, but managing the economy the right way to get your units out and be aggressive has some appeal.

The multiplayer somewhat good. The lobby is easy to navigate, and matches are quick to find. The games are RUINED by the TERRIBLE lag you get. Everything lags, and the more players you put in, the worse it gets. 1 v 1 has the game stuttering, 2 v 2 has the game going slo mo.

Get it if you want a deeper RTS game that is dated, but still good.

Pass if you want an action oriented RTS, with as little base building and economy as possible.

reviewText:
First, I'll save you some time: If you've never played Age of Mythology and like RTS games, this is definitely worth your money.  Buy it.

For everyone else.  This game is a bit buggy right now, and the graphics my computer will allow is about the same as the original game had (so poor optimization of the code, I'd say), but then again I'm on a laptop with a very poor graphics card.  For anyone with real power in their computer, I expect this would look amazing, so that's nice.

The gameplay is still fantastic.  Best RTS in my opinion.  I haven't tried the multiplayer, so I don't know how good or bad it is.  Sorry.  The original multiplayer was quite fun.

If you still own the original game, don't buy this.  Go to Voobly and have fun there.  This new edition adds...basically nothing, other than smoke and mirrors.  I wish you luck with your decision!  Maybe we can play sometime =)

reviewText:
I hate to leave this review since AOM is definetly one of my favorite games (top 5 of all time) but this whole new HD release has been ridiculous. I own the (original) physical disk but since they were releasing this HD version I thought hey I'll buy it here it'll be great to have my old favorite with some shiny new polygons. They made it sound like they nearly redid the game updating the graphics (spoiler it looks almost the same as it used to) but that's neither here nor there you don't buy a 12 year old game for the graphics anyway right you buy it for the gameplay, well......

Multiplayer, where to even begin. the short version is it doesn't work. The long version is it's bugged out something crazy random crashes, framedrops you name it. It can barely seem to hold a connection long enough to finish a match with someone. I personally got so fed up with this that I never succefully finished a multiplayer game which is awful because multiplayer back in the day was great. these bugs weren't an issue in the original version

ok so just play the single player. Well about that. Sometimes the enemy will just stand next to you non hostile and let you kill them without fighting back at all, sometimes they'll be able to produce way more troops than they should be able to (but you cannot). Your own troops (and sometimes the enemy AI as well) will get stuck between walls or buildings and even if you manually control them they can't seem to figure out how to free themselves leaving forcing you to kill them.this problem is in the main campains as well and where also not in the original version.

Finally the last straw that finally prompeted me to write this review the DLC. Now I was so excited when I heard they were making another DLC for this game especially somewhere in Asia, that has huge potiental with the possiblity of all new gods, models  and gameplay. Two out of 3 ain't bad I guess. Everything is a lazy retexture of the 1st expansion (the titans) and from what I've heard is basically a beta. I don't even own the thing so why is this my biggest issue? This icon won't even let me exit it taking me to the main page" with my real game still running in the background basically forcing me to watch my troops die. There seems to be no work around for this

recommended:
which leads me to believe this is a compulsory $10 DLC. So yea all in all 9/10 exactly as I rememebered it with a few extra lines up until stage 27 then you can get ♥♥♥♥ed.

TL;DR HD version is an embarassing buggy version of the original game with a required $10 DLC that if you don't buy will basically end your game but if you do buy will ruin it with glitches.

Oh well

reviewText:
tl;dr- Don't buy this game until the company that picked it up publicly apologizes for their bad buisness practices and actually fixes them.


Okay, this is coming from someone who owned AoMG back when it was still run by ESO. It was one of my favorite games, with tons of hours of content. It had a massive modding, and map making support and a huge number of people took advantage of this. I would always rebuy it because I wasn't paying 10$ for one game, I was paying 10$ for an infinite number. That praise isn't even mentioning the base game, with a large number of civilizations and different strategies for each. Age of Mythology Gold is an excellent game and I strongly recommend you pick it up.
The Extended Edition that steam sells is not. There has been a little bit of confusion as to who actually is running the servers and support for the Extended Edition, although the latter may be a bit of a misnomer as Age of Mythology Extended Edition is rife with errors, bugs, and inconsisntencies. There are a kalidescope of problems that can occur during a game session to cause it to crash, from disconnections (which effect a single person) to desync. For the most part the cult following on Steam has bore these burdens with resignation. They make jokes at the expense of the servers and MS Ryzon (Ex-Developer for The Extended Edition) is actually featured as a boss in one scenario. The bosses' talent? He cause lag and steals money.
We were however content to have a medium which we could play our game on once again even if this medium was buggier than an anteater's lunch infected with crabs. This changed with the recent release of the Tale of the Dragon DLC. For 10$, one could unlock the Chinese Civilization. The quality of this expansion is such, that MOST players believe it simply to be a monotized mod for the game, and a poorly done one at that. The mod plays like already existing civilizations and brings little unique to the table. What it does bring however, is a host of new errors to the game. Chat in pregame lobbies no longer work, desyncs have become far more common, and players are constantly reminded by game breaking pop-up ads to purchase the expansion pack every time a player of the Chinese Civilization does, well, anything.
The most serious problem however has appeared. Custom games no longer appear on the list of available games as they are constantly being retreived". This has rendered the largest attraction to the AoM experience completely unplayable. When I went to report this error to the support page
date: I found it broken. The Support page. Purchasing DLC is still entirely functional but attempting to to get game fixing support is impossible due to a broken link. That's the real reason for this review.The reason the player base is so frustrated isn't the errors in the game
recommended: it's the complete contempt of the paying consumers that is ultimately driving players from this game. I've asked dozens of people in the base if they have a favorable opinion of the hoster of this game. Not one single person has a favorable opinion or at very least neutral opinion of this game's hoster. The real kicker? This game was hosted 10 years ago by Ensemble Studios Online (from the makers of Halo Wars) and ran much smoother then. A company that has since collapsed was objectively more sucessful than both Steam and Skybox when it comes to smoothly running this game.\nSkyBox
hoursPlayed: if you're reading this. You need to apologize to the players of this game for bad support
voteText: bug fixes and a DLC that has only exacerbated the problem. AoM is not a difficult game to run
helpfulPercent: and it has a lot to offer to all bases. But if your inability to fix basic game errors keeps driving off old players
votesHelpful: you'll end up with a game that has no replayablity whatsoever especially when compared to the new generation of turn-based strategy."

Editor and steam workshop further enhances your experience and im sure people will come up with more mods to upgrade both graphics and gameplay.

reviewText:
Age of Mythology, a game a lot of people remember as a fun, intense and challencing game right out of childhood. I recall it as one of the first games I ever played.
I've heard critics say that this version of the game is just a graphical facelift, and that it's way too overpriced for an old title.
I on the other hand think the exact opposite. I think that the game is the same game, but that makes me happy, as I can relive my childhood in it.
I think the adaptation of Steam Workshop, and the new way of making Mods to the game, could breed some pretty interesting mods.
Yes it has it's flaws, it's bound to have. I believe that Age of Mythology: Extended Edition you buy if you were a great fan of the game.

reviewText: As far as I can tell, it feels like the original game patched to have mordern-ish graphics with a few bonuses. For those like me who have played the original and looked to this expecting something more refined, even if nothing new, you came to the wrong place! Most of the bugs in the original seem to still be around. I personally bought it to play with my friends online, but that is probably the most laughable thing there is. The application seems to use a client-side host with the steamworks intergration to connect players to eachothers servers. This alone isn't a bad thing, but the server seems so poorly optmized it feels that even the best of IPS will probably still have pretty bad lag. Simply put, steaming a YouTube video in HD is probably less taxing on your internet. Probably the worse part is the game has MEMORY LEAKS! Numerious times have myself and other players I know had there entire progress eradicated because of a memory allocation error which completely crashes the game. Rule of thumb in software development: critical bugs should not exist in finished products. Crashing to you desktop with a Memory System Error" pop up is less than graceful and definitely counts as a critical bug."

reviewText:
First of all, I've never played AoM or AoE or anything like this before, neither any strategy game like this. A friend of mine wanted to buy it and asked me if I wanted to share the four pack. I agreed and plled two more friends in...

I loved playing Dota 2, but now, even when I miss racing around the map as Bloodseeker, I'm more willing to play AoM, because I loved it.

I always play with a friend of mine, one of the two I pulled in, and he had already played it long eons ago, so he taught me the basics and we play cooperatively, almost like one civilization with two players... except our civilizations are never the same.

For issues about connection, I admit there are some, but issues from Dota 2 are far worse than these, and mostly, I know it isn't the game's fault, but my friend's poor connection.

The only real problem is... this game is just a ilttle expensive.... just the price to eat for a month... depending on how much you eat of course.

So I suggest: put it on your wishlist and wait for steam's crazy discounts. The 4-pack we shared was for a bit more than $10.00 ... divided by four people. Plus, my share of the price was given as birthday gift.

reviewText:
I have owned the original AoM since it's release and it is one of my favourite games. I never had the Titans expansion so that's why I bought this remake/Extended Edition/whatyouwannacallit. Visuals are great and music is still memorable. Campaign keeps you well occupied but the objectives are just repetitive sometimes. You usually start with a few villagers and your task is to destroy enemys camp. Repeat that and repeat it again. Still I keep coming back because the story is very good for a strategy game, as you could expect from AoE series. Maps in classic skirmish and campaign modes are also often very detailed and so it encourages you to scout every black spot to find hidden relics which can help you with your mission.

The myth units bring a nice new twist to the old RTS formula but matches dont become a Minotaur spamfest as myth units are usually much more expensive than regular human units. Famous folklore heroes like Hercules and Achilles are also there and they take mythic beasts down like the bosses they are. Everything is pretty nice and balanced like a rock-paper-scissors game.

Gods from old greek, egyptian and nordic mythologies play a major part in game. Every civilization has 3 main gods and they all have six minor gods who give you different kind of god powers like meteorite rain, ability to mind control monkeys or making your villages to gather food faster (lame!). A well used god power can turn a game upside down but they can be used only once so when and where to use them is critical.

If you already own AoM and it's expansions don't bother buying this as theres very little new to offer for oldtimers. But if you don't have AoM what are you waiting for? This game is accessible for newcomers and offers a fair challenge for hardened strategy veterans. Buy it and love it!

reviewText:
An RTS game where you get to lead armies supported by the creatures of Greek, Egyptian, and Norse Mythology? ♥♥♥♥ING SOLD.

I did play the original version of this game... so many years ago. While it did not capture me quite like Age of Empires II did, AoM was still pretty good. In this remade version... well I don't really see any changes from the original, except for stuff like Steam support, being able to run on modern OS', and the usual stuff you see when an old game is remade for the present day. All important, of course, but for those who have already played AoM, there isn't really anything new here.

As usual, I stuck to single-player since I'm a terrible online RTS player. The main campaign here drags on a bit long, but it is still plenty good and worthy of the Age RTS series. The expansions' campaigns, which I had never played until now, were also pretty neat in their own way. I still prefer AoE II's campaigns, but... nothing really beats those in my book. I am biased. XD

Ultimately, it's just good old RTS fun, except this time you can literally storm your enemies with Hydras, Anubites, or Valkyries instead of the usual hordes of spearmen, archers, and cavalry. Woohoo!

Enjoy! :D

reviewText:
A classic of the RTS genre, Age of Mythology greatly played to my love of the Greek and Egyptian Mythologies and introduced me to the Norse. Mind you this was back when AoM was first released back in 2002. I loved it then and I loved it now.

The game plays like your standard Age of Empires styled RTS game. Gather resources, build an army, topple your enemies. This game introduces a unique resource known as Favor which is generated differently across the 4 factions of the game. The Greeks require villagers to worship at the temple, Egyptians build up to 5 monuments, the Norse gain favor through battle, and the Atlantians gain favor by controling Town Centers. Favor can be spent to purchase specific god related upgrades or train myth units which can give you an edge.

Each facton can, technically, be broken down into three subfactions divided up by the major god the faction uses. Greeks can worship Zeus, Hades, or Posedeon, Egyptians worship Ra, Isis, or Set, Norse worship Thor, Odin, or Loki, and the Atlantians worship Kronos, Oranos, or Gaia. Each major god carries their own unique god powers and other benefits upon their faction. For instance, following Thor grants you access to a Dwarven Gold Mine which, depending on the age in which it is used, acts as a free bonus Gold Mine for players to use. Similarly Thor allows for the construction of a Dwarven Armory which researches cheaper upgrades than average armories.

Each major god also has a select list of minor gods for you to choose from when advancing from one age to the next. You can only pick one of two gods to worship and will gain the benefits from that god once you reach the next age. Each minor god grants you a special myth unit to use and each myth unit has its own unique traits. For example the Egyptian Scarab is a living siege unit designed to destroy enemy structures, the Greek Pegasus is a flying scout, etc. Each of the minor gods includes unique upgrades that can be researched that affect specific groups like cavalry, villagers, infantry, etc.

The god powers for each faction also differs. The Atlantians have a slight advantage with their god powers as some of them carry multiple charges and can be used more than once after a cooldown period. Up to 4 god powers can be acquired at a time, with your initial power coming from your major god and three subsiquent powers being gained from the minor gods.

In addition to basic units, there are also hero units. Hero units are the counter to myth units as they're meant for just that purpose of eliminiating the myth units. Each faction has their own hero units. Egyptians have Priests and the Pharoh, Norse have a hammer wielding melee hero, and Atlantians can promote any one of their infantry or cavalry units into heroes for a price. Greeks seem to have the short end as they only get up to 4 heroes at a time and these heroes may vary between infantry, cavalry, or archer. However the Greek Heroes have their own unique abilities such as Ajax being able to bash enemy units away with his large shield.

And then there are the Titans! The Titans were introduced with the Titans expansion and AoM is probably one of the first games to introduce a game changing uber-unit. Upon reaching the mythic age, each faction can place a Titan Gate which, once it is uncovered/constructed by the faction's builder units, releases a Titan which is a massive and powerful melee unit that deals unbelievable damage and in most cases can obliterate an entire army singlehandedly. The only drawback to the Titans are that their health is finite and any health lost is lost forever and if the Titan dies, you don't get another one. The most effective counter to a Titan is another Titan or a host of ranged hero units. The Atlantians seem to have a slight advantage here as if the minor goddess Hecate is worshiped, a special bonus of hers allows all myth units to gradually regenerate their health, and Titans are concidered myth units.

The only real drawback to the game is that you're fixed to only one camera angle with a top down view. This is from 2002 so that can be forgiven as a dated mechanic." Your army size is limited to 200 population points max and most units take up at least two or more population points so you're not going to have armies numbering in the thousands. You'll be lucky to have an army in the dozens. Villagers also count against the population cap. Another frustration with the population cap is that population is determined by the number of houses or town centers you have. Greeks
recommended: and Norse can build up to 10 houses to increase their population while Atlantians can build up to 5 Manors which offer the same benefit but can also be garrisoned by other units for defense. After that
hoursPlayed: the only way to increase your unit cap is to build additional town centers and those can only be built on top of pre-existing settlements in the world and those settlements may or may not be in an optimal position. You could easily find an availible perilously close to your enemy's camp. If the map has a water feature such as a large lake or a chain of islands that isolate you from your enemy
voteText: be ready to use up half of your population to building naval defenses as ships count against the population count too. And don't bother summoning your titan from the safey of your base if you're on an island because then it becomes a glorified watchdog as Titans cannot board transports and cannot go across the water. They're landlocked so if you use up that titan gate
helpfulPercent: you're stuck with a titan at your base. Great for defense if the enemy makes it to shore (No ranged attack on the Titan
votesHelpful: remember) but besides that...\n\nAlso be very careful on where you use your titan gate power because if you demolish it by accident or it gets destroyed by your enemy
votesTotal: you don't get it back and its gone forever along with all chances of your getting a titan
votesFunny: especially if you've got one baring down on your base.\n\nStill
commentsCount: Age of Mythology is an RTS that should be played by every RTS fan.\n\nThere is also an interesting piece of news. Age of Mythology may very well be the first game ever to recieve an expansion pack update for the first time since the last official update 13 years after the game was released. The Tale of the Dragon Expansion Pack is supposed to include an all new faction: The Chinese and include figures and deities from Chinese mythology. The expansion pack is set to be released on January 28th of this year. And just to give you some perspective
column16: The original Age of Mythology was released in 2002 with the Titans Expansion releasing the year after in 2003. Now we're getting an expansion pack in 2016. That's almost 14 years after the game came out. For a game to be this old and recieve an update like this 14 years later is definately something worth noting."

reviewText: Mmm~ if you played this years back and wanted to do so on modern systems today like I did, this doesn't disappoint.  Basically the same delectable game (and one of my favorite RTS games of all time) as it was back then, with a few bugs in transition, but largely nothing game breaking, since last I remember they fixed the Steamworks issues I had with inviting my friend.\n\nFor nostalgia buyers, you're going to get exactly what you think you're getting.  My only complaint is the rather high price tag for literally the same, old game, but eh, whatever.  Perhaps some of the magic is lost from when I played this as one of my first actual" computer games when I was younger
date: but it all still holds up
recommended: and I can now appreciate the competitive and game design side of things
hoursPlayed: even if I am too chicken to play matchmaking.\n\nFor newcomers
voteText: I like to think the game has a very welcoming feel.  The art style is appropriate and iconic
helpfulPercent: the units are unique and every one of them has unique voice lines and voice effects
votesHelpful: and the music is some of the best ambient tracks I know of.  Units respond snappily and intelligently
votesTotal: the interface is clean and streamlined
votesFunny: and I can't think of a single gripe with the resource management and building.  Er
column16: the walls are sometimes a bit annoying to construct
column17: but I rarely used those.\n\nThe game also comes with a concise and bite-size encyclopedia (accessible at any given time - even in game) of all of the gods and units included in the game and their usage and role in their given society
column18: which is actually fascinating to read and largely attributed to my modest knowledge of the mythologies today.  Overall
column19: I have no regrets buying the same game at a probably higher price than I got it before."

reviewText: I have been playing this game since 2005 and it was nice to finally play this game again with new textures. Of course there are also a few things that were added. Steam Workshop is one of them and it makes downloading mods much easier. Twitch was also built into the game to make live streaming the game easier. Day and night was also added to give a realistic feel to the game when playing on a map for a long time.\n\nThe graphics on the game are good along with a few other things but I found a few things to be a bit too polished. Overall I found Age of Mythology EX to be a great game if you are into RTS games and enjoy a good story line.

You could easily find an availible perilously close to your enemy's camp. If the map has a water feature such as a large lake or a chain of islands that isolate you from your enemy
voteText: be ready to use up half of your population to building naval defenses as ships count against the population count too. And don't bother summoning your titan from the safey of your base if you're on an island because then it becomes a glorified watchdog as Titans cannot board transports and cannot go across the water. They're landlocked so if you use up that titan gate
helpfulPercent: you're stuck with a titan at your base. Great for defense if the enemy makes it to shore (No ranged attack on the Titan
votesHelpful: remember) but besides that...\n\nAlso be very careful on where you use your titan gate power because if you demolish it by accident or it gets destroyed by your enemy
votesTotal: you don't get it back and its gone forever along with all chances of your getting a titan
votesFunny: especially if you've got one baring down on your base.\n\nStill
commentsCount: Age of Mythology is an RTS that should be played by every RTS fan.\n\nThere is also an interesting piece of news. Age of Mythology may very well be the first game ever to recieve an expansion pack update for the first time since the last official update 13 years after the game was released. The Tale of the Dragon Expansion Pack is supposed to include an all new faction: The Chinese and include figures and deities from Chinese mythology. The expansion pack is set to be released on January 28th of this year. And just to give you some perspective
column16: The original Age of Mythology was released in 2002 with the Titans Expansion releasing the year after in 2003. Now we're getting an expansion pack in 2016. That's almost 14 years after the game came out. For a game to be this old and recieve an update like this 14 years later is definately something worth noting."

reviewText: I have been playing this game since 2005 and it was nice to finally play this game again with new textures. Of course there are also a few things that were added. Steam Workshop is one of them and it makes downloading mods much easier. Twitch was also built into the game to make live streaming the game easier. Day and night was also added to give a realistic feel to the game when playing on a map for a long time.\n\nThe graphics on the game are good along with a few other things but I found a few things to be a bit too polished. Overall I found Age of Mythology EX to be a great game if you are into RTS games and enjoy a good story line.

reviewText: I have played this game for a long time as you can see. This game is great and i love it. There are many, many problems with it though. The majority of the people on the game are terrible. There are so many bugs now, that its not even worth playing at this stage. You will desync the majority of the games, and the games that you don't will be quick. The only way to get a good game is to find friends that are at your skill level. To be honest, I only recommend this game to those who will take the time to deal with the bugs. Hopefully, the AOM team haven't given up on us, and are working to fix these bugs, but it doesn't really seem like they are. Good luck, and if you get the game, I hope you enjoy

reviewText:
You Shouldn't Take any advice from those 'Not Recommended' Review's. I have had this game for a very long time, eventually i got it on steam just to make sure i could get the patches and workshop content. Most people are complaining about bugs here and there without looking up the patches, When the first dlc released i had a huge patch for my basegame, and i only just realized now that, that patch was actually all the content for the new dlc, just restricted untill purchased, so my game has been running completely fine without the dlc, and now that i bought the dlc it's still running perfectly.

Pro's : Great game 9/10
Run's smoothly
Easy to learn
Fantastic Storyline
Well working A.I
Heap's of Map's
DLC $9.99


Con's : Not as popular as it should be
Rarely Allied A.I is useless

Note about the dlc, it's very similar to the chinese faction in age of empires 3 asian dynasties.

reviewText: In all honesty, this is an Upgrade to the once famous Age of Mythology, I mean all of the new features are fine and dandy and they help secure this game's continued loglivity (you could also play on Garena or Game Ranger before EE came to Steam) but they just feel so... expensive, I of course had to have this game in my grips again because it was one of my Childhood games that I used to play besides Battlefield 1942 and the Army Men series. I started out with the demo of the game before I bought the psychical copy but I was too late, the multiplayer was dead, or at least I didn't know about Game Ranger and Garena at the time and I played the game by default, and now a few months before EE came to Steam I started modding and doing stuff with it, and now I can continue doing it and have a wider audience at the game's workshop which I am very glad, but again, the price tag which was put on the EE is pretty high if you ask me, I mean, 15 or 20 dollars yes but not more. Don't get me wrong tho, I enjoy the game and I will continue to enjoy it, and I am glad that I bought it, I have always though of it as the Mythological Starcraft kind of game and it has always felt like it, but I want to do great and epic battles in the game so I'll see what I can do to make it happen so if you see my review and buy the game make sure to check out the workshop, you'll find some great mods there, go see aomheaven.com too, they got some pre EE and pre Steam stuff for the game there too, heck you might even find some of my mods on the workshop here.

reviewText: Great game. It\'s very accurate in terms of mythology. If you\'ve played Age of Empires then you\'ll no doubt love this game. It\'s very hands on. I enjoy the graphics and sounds. The buildings are well done along with the story. The AI can seem a bit broken at times, but it\'s way nicer than Age of Empires AI, so that\'s a sight to see. Though there are parts that can get rather boring, it makes up for it with quick-play matches, and even a multiplayer system. The units are very ranged and it\'s interesting when you play as different groups like Nords, Egyptians, Greeks, etc. The system is very easy to learn and understand so even if you\'re new to these kind of games it\'s nothing to be scared of. Overall, a good strategy game.

reviewText:
Dodgy and unncessessary recreation of the original.

The online support is pathetic, with a game which was previously capable of running on a dial-up internet connection, now incapable of running on a broadband connection without intense lag which only increases with each additional player. Pathfinding is far worse, meaning that often you have to navigate units manually around obstacles. Sounds appear to either not play or be missing in some cases, leaving a massive tornado totally silent while the music merrily hums along in the background.

In some places graphics have been rendered worse than how they originally appear, farms seem de-saturated and fish have a bizarre pixelation in the ocean.

When playing with a group of friends against bots (the lag was intoloerable, a player on my own network was also lagging as well as myself - the player who started the game), we had the same colour green used for both a member of our team and the enemy team. This lead to a lot of confusion.

To summarize, just don't buy it.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Get the old one, if you are able to make it work on your system.

Plus:

+ In MP, player management was integrated in steam UI, making it probably easier to invite friends

Neutral:

. HD rework makes it possile to play in higher res. However, game looks slightly weird and nothing else seems to have been improved graphically

Negative:

- MP experience constantly lagging to some degree
- Game sometimes lags while scrolling despite of mediocre graphics and an up-to-date pc
- No bugfixing whatsoever, game still goes out of sync from time to time like the original version
- limited player base, bad connections, overall MP experience (i.e. last night, from 5 games only one ended with loss/victory, all others were decided by a player dc'ing, getting out of sync)

Overall assessment: AoM EE is not worth 28€ by far. Only buy if not able to play the old version. MP experience very bad.

reviewText: I was a huge fan of the original version of this game and I was excited for a chance to own it again and play it with my friends, even at the rather absurd price for this thing. Unfortunately, 90% of the time, it's completely unplayable. This is the worst lag I have ever experienced in a steam game, up to 15-20 seconds per in game second with little to no letting up. This experience is universal among all my friends who I got this game with, regardless of who they're playing or where they are. If you're looking at getting it, I recommend Age of Empires instead, despite the buggy and incompetent AI if you're looking to play this with anyone else. I don't recommend buying this before it's fixed, though this has been brought up so many times since it's been released, I doubt it will be.

reviewText:
Unstable with annoying bugs:

Played this game over many years on a ton of different machines.  This has always been a solid game that, now that I think of it, has never crashed or glitched on me.  So when I fired this up for a trip down memory lane I was not impressed to find a few problems:

1. Units stacks report incorrect numbers.
2. Myth units stuck in combat (special moves on empty ground after a kill)
3. And the final straw - game bombed out on my halfway through a fun random map

Whatever tinkering you've done to improve" this classic game isn't really worth it if it's gonna crash."

reviewText:
I cannot believe I have to give this a negative review.. This was a MARVELOUS game, but Microsoft has proven it likes to take games and mold them into a money printer. And that's what this game turned into. This game has almost no support form my recent beginning to play the game. There is much to despair over multiplayer and this is very unfortunate.
My reasons Extended Edition should not be bought:
-Lag across the board in multiplayer, regardless of how beefy your computer is, online or LAN
-God Powers can desync Online games and make it easy to abuse ranking
-Conversion of old maps is made incredibly difficult due to the addition of some stupid 'Alfred' unit
-There is no report button anywhere, so if you're getting trolled/bashed, you have to cope or stop playing online
-Single Player shows it's problems in cutscenes. Wrong Angles or complete terrain obscurity.
-HD simply means, you can't find the fish while trying to fish. And a useless Day/Night cycle, that is never used.
-Sometimes things happen for no good reasons, such as finishing a Titan Gate and it disapears.

I bought this to relive a classic and play online, sadly, this wasn't the case. Skybox games should never be purchased.

reviewText:
EDIT: I literally just finished writing this review and then saw the RPS link that they're announcing a new expansion on chinese mythology. At the moment I still hold my stance on the game, But I will re-pick it up when the expansion comes out and change my review accordingly.

As a long time fan of both Age of Empires and Age of Mythology, I'm going to say that unless you have an extreme attachment to Age of Mythology, go with the HD Remake of Age of Empires II for now. I'm writing this on the 2015/2016 christmas season, so maybe in the future this review will become outdated, but at the time of writing there is little support for this game compared to the other HD Remake of the same series.

Firstly, Age of Empires has gotten 2 DLC packs that are both great. Expansions and improvements to a 15+ year old game. Rebalances and slight tweaks all the way to adding brand new techs to change the viability of certain kinds of play. I'm not expecting Age of Mythology to get anywhere near adding new expansions to the game as Age of Mythology is a much more advanced and complicated game with more going on, which takes quite a lot more time and materials to get it running- but the fact of the matter is that Age of Mythology EX hasn't gotten nearly any updates that mean anything since it has come out, in both gameplay aspects and technical aspects. Age of Empires II HD was extremely laggy in online and broken in multiple ways when it first came out, and so was Age of Mythology EX. The difference is that Age of Empires II HD actually fixed most of it's problems through patches, while Age of Mythology EX still chugs on some systems by managing to run worse than the original game even with lower graphical settings and online is still a buggy mess. There are apparently memory leaks within the game too, which make it slowly stutter as the game goes on, especially when the unit cap increases too.

This isn't really an offensively bad port, otherwise. I can't really say I am downright angry with this upgrade to steam, actually I'm kind of glad it happened so I can at least play half of a match (before it randomly disconnects) with friends again without having to go through confusing game channels. The game is still the same as before, nothing awful has changed... If you don't like the Day/Night cycles you can turn them off as far as I remember, and the updated water gets turned back closer to what it was like in the original if you have you graphics turned down low enough (at least from my testing). Overall, I am still going to play this game and enjoy it, and if you're a huge fan of this game you will enjoy it too- but if you're just considering this or another Age of XXXX game, AoE2HD is a much, much better upgrade currently and will not eviscerate your system if you're running something mildly old.

reviewText:
Bought this game again to re-experience a game I absolutely loved as a kid, it was easily one of my favorite RTS' at the time. So going back to it after all these years would be great right?

Well...no. Unfortunately the game hasn't aged all that well. At all. Gameplay is far slower and clunkier than I remember it being, which is strange since it feels slower than Age of Empires 2 (Which has aged far better than this game).

The graphics arn't stylistic enough to still look good, it looks more like Nintendo 64 level than anything that was the standard at the time. While the environments and buildings tend to look pretty good, the units just look fairly lackluster. Gameplay is just so god damned slowed, even the battles feel so slow and clunky you would think you were running it at the slowest speed possible. In concept units all have counters for one another, some units are better are killing certain units than others, but unless you're an expert at micromanaging in practice it just proves completely worthless.

Even when I tried micromanaging my units according to their counters, combat was still slower than molasses and just felt overall unsatisfying. Defenses feel almost worthless in this game as well, no matter how well constructed your base defenses are simple infantry can just break through it in no time. The myth units are still overpowered as ever, even if you counter them with heroes.

Also the new expansion doesn't add anything particularly worthwhile. The idea is awesome! Ancient chinese units and myths all integrated into a new faction! In practice, it's nothing special at all. It feels like Greek-Lite more than anything. The campaign it adds is just so bland and uninteresting as well. Speaking of, the main campaign of the story is bland and uninteresting overall, with only a few levels that really rise up to being great (Arkantos' Dream being the most prominent). All of it boils down to Build up base
date: take down X." with very little variation or story bits in the middle.\n\nWhile this would normally be nothing to really complain about (since that's the core of an RTS afterall)
recommended: the slow and uninteresting gameplay piled on top of that makes the Campaign feel like a complete and utter grind.\n\nThe concept is still fantastic
hoursPlayed: but in practice it's really just not all that great a game. I've went back and played quite a few older RTS' and sadly AOM just doesn't hold up like its brothers and sisters of the time. I loved this game once
voteText: but going back and playing it? I can't really remember why I loved it."

reviewText:
If you're looking for a RTS single player experience, this game is good for you, if you're looking for a RTS to play with anyone that isn’t on fiber internet speeds, do not buy this game. This game instead of using dedicated servers uses a peer to peer system in which if a single person is lagging (due to a moderate or slow internet connection) the entire game for everyone will lag.

Overall, this is a disappointment especially since the original game worked on dial-up speeds. Therefore I would not recommend buying this game.

reviewText:
This is an old RTS game from 2002
I usually refrain from buying  old games that were released before 2007 as  most have been a terrible disapointment. Even though the graphics look old, outdated and haven't been improved much at all, the game is ok to play.


I find the game mostly enjoyable to play even though it is an ugly game with graphics from 2000. And with AOM  Extended Edition, doesn't seem like much  has been added or changed/improved. It says improved graphics, but it doesn't look like it, all that seems to have improved is a bit of water texture, shadow and some lighting and it's still ugly old outdated textures.

I like how there is a mythological aspect to the game, it makes it more interesting for me, to choose a god and have various powers you can evoke, though rather limited, powers such as call down a bolt of lightning to instant kill a enemy. And a devastating meteor that will destroy a small area. These powers are very limited though, only being able to use once per map, so should be used wisely.
I also like that there are heroes and myth units, creatures like minotaurs and hydra that become stronger and grow another head after a kill.

I get bored playing too much, usually after a couple of hours, as all it is, is fighting and nothing much else. And I feel happy when I complete a campaign scenario and then feel disapointed that there's another one to complete. So I probably don't like the campaign game much as it drags on and on.
The campaign takes way too long to complete, usually I like lengthy games, but not when the story involved is rather boring and the scenario missions don't differ much as every one is mostly just build your base up, build army, attack and defeat. I just want it to hurry up and be over already. The campaign should be 15 to 20 scenarios at most, not 32. I prefer to play just random maps in short bursts.

And it's frustrating when you get halfway through a scenario, only to have the game crash and you try and reload a recent save but the save file is stuffed and wont load so have to start the scenario from the begining again.

I liked the game over all and say it's worth getting and playing at a discounted price for $10 or less, but not for full price as it's just an old rehashed game which has outdated graphics and not many improvements. Nothing that modernises or makes it feel worthy of the so called Extended title.

6/10 ok.

reviewText:
Here we are again with another of Ensemble's games.  Ensemble, in case you're wondering, is an old PC dev that published under microsoft then went bankrupt.  This game?  I've heard good things about it.  Will I ever know if it's good or not?  No.  Why?  Well, this isn't actually the game we knew.  It's a copy-and-paste remake by Skybox Labs, but one part was changed [for the worse]-- the netcode.

Its netcode is ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.  Let me just tell you about ONE match, one that was in LAN... 17 out of sync errors, an army that recognizes orders up to 2 seconds later than you clicked, a screen that only renders enemy armies on the minimap, but doesn't show you the actual army until 5 seconds after they've supposedly come close enough to see, in which they lag-teleport forward.

I don't know why I trusted these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s at Skybox a second time.  This is the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t they pulled with Age of Empires 2 HD Edition
date: a fake HD edition (looked just as old as classic, textures that were changed I changed back because they looked like ♥♥♥♥) with a terrible netcode as well.  This time, perhaps they didn't sell off somebody's modwork as paid DLC, but it's still just as unplayable as AoE2.\n\nDo not recommend under any circumstances.  Final verdict: Go buy it on disc from Amazon for around $8, new condition.  The original game's only from 2007, so compatibility issues are only a problem on Windows 8 in which case some have fixed it and I'm sure there are directions to fixing the game for Win8.

reviewText:
Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is the enhanced version of the classic RTS game Age of Mythology (2002). It plays a lot like Age of Empires series, but with the use of god powers (spells alike), mythycal units and the controversial Titan, an extremely OP unit used to crush entire armies.

Those accustomed to Age of Empires II (like me) will have to develop new strategies. Rushing and spamming units is a lot less efficient in AoM, because you can't build a lot of houses before claim new settlements (town centers) and the power of gods adds spicy situations that can turn the table in a favor of a player. Also, AoM has a lot less nations, but they're extremely different and will take you a lot of matchs to master them.

The Extended Edition has graphics improvements, HD support, new online features (like the observer mode and Twitch integration) and steamworks features, like the Workshop, where you can download new maps, texture packs, etc. It comes with the Titans expansion (2003) and the extra official campaign Golden Gift". To beat all campaigns it will take 20+ hours. There's a lot of map types and game modes to play in Skirmish and Multiplayer. The replay value is high enough to keep you hooked for a long

reviewText:
This is one of my favorite stategy games of all time, so seeing it upgraded with better graphics, and the promise of easy mulitiplayer via steam, it was a no brainer for me.  I bought it up and installed it right away!

The game graphics while not a HUGE diffrence were noticable enough to be a positive.  The water especially was good looking.  The shadows were also a major improvment over the old style circle shadows beneath people.

However, this game falls very short, very VERY short, when it comes to multiplayer.  I was unable to even get in a game after 5 minutes of waiting with superb internet.  This simply is unplayable online.

So if your buying this game for strictly single player purposes, i'd say go ahead.  But DON'T buy this for multiplayer.  that was such a big let down..

reviewText:
IT'S HAPPENING!?!?!?!?


For many of us Age of Mythology is a game very close to our hearts. For those unfamiliar with the game, it is essentially a Real Time Strategy game, much like Age of Empires - but with heroes and mythical units too. While their are only four main factions to choose from (greek, egyptian, norse, atlanteans), each faction has numerous gods to choose from, and the diversity of not only the mythical units, but the standard human units as well, is impressive.

The single player campaign is very well designed, with good level design throughout, and you will want to play it through more than once. While the Multiplayer is where the true fun lies, the single player is still worthy as a stand-alone game. Do not be afraid of trying out multiplayer though. Sure - there will be some very good people playing online, but do not be disheartened. Soon you will be (and I'm sure many of us have already experienced this) spending countless hours trying different game modes and developing new strategies to crush the heathan(s) opposing you. Also if you can get some mates together to play then all the merrier!

Even though there appear to be some technical issues with the steam edition, let us just hope that they work out similar to those that were present in the Age of Empires Steam edition (which have since been fixed).

If you have not experienced Age of Mythology, then I would whole-heartedly recommend it. If you have already played it then you may be a bit sceptical about handing out money for something you already own. What you are really paying for is the steam support for multiplayer. Finding games to play will be much simpler, because I can assure you that there will be a lot of people playing this game. A great game with an active and passionate community should not be simply passed by.

9/10 would nostalgia again.

reviewText:
I'm sure every long-time AoM fan wants and/or already has this game, but those who are considering buying this game: DON'T. Those top two reviews on the game's store page are from beta testers. Fun fact: Some beta testers are paid by the game devs to say good things about their game no matter how much of a crapstain it is. By now you're probably wondering when I'm gonna get to the specs. Well, I'm doing that now.

God portraits are even WORSE than the original, and so are the graphics. THE GRAPHICS! It's common sense that when a 12-year-old game is given a new HD rerelease, it's in HD. This isn't one of those rereleases.
It takes an incredibly high-end computer to run this game; Most laptops suffer either hard crashes or unplayably low FPS (less than 10 FPS). The FPS is even worse on multiplayer. Most of the time people lag out and your game's over.
You can buy the Gold Edition of the original AoM (AoM + Titans expansion) on Amazon  for less than a third of the Steam price [i.imgur.com]. If you're asking But what about m-muh Golden Gift?" Golden Gift is a 4-level "mini-expansion"  available for FREE on the Microsoft website [www.microsoft.com]

Basically
date: Microsoft's ripping you off right now. DON'T buy this game."

reviewText: This game can play a lot more glitchy and slow compared to the original version. It is at its worst online because of lag issues, even when both/all people have a good internet connection it can lag quite a bit. Even when playing offline to me it seems to run worse then the original when playing both side by side, and the textures can seem a bit off for some things like the fish which seemed blurry and indistinct.\nBut I'm sure all these problems can be fixed, hopefully soon and it is still tons of fun. It allows multi-player via steam which makes playing with friends and online in general much easier, still it is a bit pricey for such an old game with its issues and understandably too much for some. I would recommend it to anyone who loved the game and/or wants to play it with friends/people online as hopefully it will only get better.\n

reviewText: This is the third time I've purchased this game.\n\nAOM is my favourite in the age of" series by a large amount. While an old game now I still have fun jumping on it here and there and having a few games with friends of against the AI. For people who have yet to play this game
date: don't be put off by the mythological theme. This is still a great game that will give you the same satisfaction that you have gotten from the other titles.\n\nThe campaign is fun and quite a lengthy investment. The expansion added campaign following the original is fantastic as well. You can live without the dwarves focused one
recommended: while it has some fun ideas for maps it's short
hoursPlayed: easy and lacks any real depth . The main problem I had with these in the newest steam version was that the graphical quality seems to have been dramatically reduced. I played the old version less than six months ago on a ten year old laptop and it looked better than this version on my new $3k rig.\n\nThe day and night cycle is over rated and really serves no point

if anything I found it broke the game up more and turned it off.

Multiplayer is fun but expect to play against strong players.

Random AI matches are the same as before but with two new game types. They can be fun but I've always been a conquest or occasionally supremacy fan.

reviewText: I used to play this game when I was about 5 or 6.  I didn't know how to do much in this at the time, but it was amazingly fun.  Then the disc got scratched up.  My friend fixed it 7 years later and found it to be as much fun.  Once I saw the extended edition come up on Steam, I got excited.  Finally, the water isnt just a blue slime that it looked like whenever I played the original.  This game is great, but its very pricey for $30.  If you want some fun strategy, get this on sale.  If you a mythology geek like me, you may find the campaign to be a bit weird, but they stay true to most of the mythology.

reviewText:
This is one of my favorite stategy games of all time, so seeing it upgraded with better graphics, and the promise of easy mulitiplayer via steam, it was a no brainer for me.  I bought it up and installed it right away!

The game graphics while not a HUGE diffrence were noticable enough to be a positive.  The water especially was good looking.  The shadows were also a major improvment over the old style circle shadows beneath people.

However, this game falls very short, very VERY short, when it comes to multiplayer.  I was unable to even get in a game after 5 minutes of waiting with superb internet.  This simply is unplayable online.

So if your buying this game for strictly single player purposes, i'd say go ahead.  But DON'T buy this for multiplayer.  that was such a big let down..

reviewText:
Minus playing the scenario's (never crashed once for the story scenario's at least) through for a decent story / play, this game seems to love to crash when you play VS games >>>>>>A LOT<<<<<<< If you remember to save it every 5 minutes or so (lolwut) it isn't a big deal I guess. Seems like the same memory leak that was around when it first came out. Sometimes it happens randomly, other times it crashes out if I play 1 AI game after just playing a game. Sometimes I can restart the game, then play another match with no issues, other times it will crash anyways. I mean who wants to pay for a game that cannot even be played half of the time, who wants to put hours into a match to see it crash and lose all progression???

What is weird is, when I bought the original AoM and the expansion I never had it crash at all, not sure what is up there, maybe it hates windows 10 as much as the rest of us do? Which brings up another fun thing, I had one hell of a hard time getting this game to install, ended up doing a system restore just so I could even play this game.... For a bit at least, then I see my desktop backround again :p


After my latest crash, I just don't have the energy to go back and replay however long ago it was from my last save point I had to make, just in case..... So I write an angry review instead.



1/5 stars till someone fixes that bulls***
I cant in good conscience recommend a broken product to people (maybe if its on sale dirt cheap whatever then).

5/5 for any RTS lover who doesn't mind replaying the same thing they just did 4 hours ago due to the game crashing (lolz)

reviewText:
This is one of my all time favorite RTS games, it's up there with other timeless classics like C&C Red Alert 2 and StarCraft. It's basically Age of Empires in 3D and with monsters and god powers.

When it comes to the Extended Edition, I like how they updated the visuals without changing too much, because of this, most mods for the original game work with this version. (Mods which replace rextures are not compatible and need to be converted, which is a pain.)
One thing I don't like about the new effects and graphics is that you can't turn them off, which will make some older, less powerful systems that could run the original (like my laptop) struggle to run this version.

Obviously this version comes with The Titans expansion and The Golden Gift mini campaign, which is great.

Final note: As great as this game is, it's a little dated and is a little expensive for an old game. If it goes on sale for under 20$, that would a good time to buy it. That said, there aren't that many RTS games coming out these days and it might be worth paying a little more for such a great RTS.

reviewText:
Gameplay is virtually unchanged since its original release in 2002, leaving the balance (or unbalance) of the game intact. Because of this, and since the original game still runs on modern computers in HD resolutions, I'll be focusing entirely on what this installment brings to the table.

1. Improved visuals: But not really.

Much like the AoE2 re-release, Mythology was given a visual overhaul by the new studio. What this means is that they've tacked on new graphical features, without much considering of how this will benefit players. You'll see things such as GLOBAL LIGHTING and BLURRY WATER FILTER. Whether these really improve anything lies mostly in the eyes of the beholder; but for those who played the original, the new look will be discomforting and sometimes hindering (on certain maps, your units will be difficult to see).

2. Social gaming: A.k.a. the Steam Experience".

Because custom maps is half the fun
hoursPlayed: but unlike the visual improvements
voteText: this is actually a feature that is only beneficial
helpfulPercent: and does not hinder anyone who's not interested in it. So
votesHelpful: in that sense
votesTotal: this is the best thing to come out of the Extended Edition. However
votesFunny: it does not - and will not ever - weigh heavily enough to be worthy of the 30€ price tag.\n\nBut what about all the other awesome Steam-exlusive features that you won't find in the original 2002 release? Because a PC game without achievements and trading cards doesn't belong in 2014 - said no one ever

column18: for instant access. No
column21:
hardly a worthy selling point.

3. Extended Features: Watch other people play.

Just as Age 2 HD was given Twitch Integration
column22: Mythology was as well. This is a rising trend in video games
column23: and I can't see anything wrong with it. Is it a necessary feature for the re-release of a 12 year old game? Probably not; but it doesn't hurt. But - and this seems to be the theme of this review - it is hardly worth the 30€ price tag. Streaming to Twitch is free with software like OBS
column24:
and also provides tenfolds more options than any integrated feature ever will.

In conclusion: Don't waste your money

Unlike the Age 2 re-release

reviewText:
It's twelve years later and this game is still a blast to play. It's gotten so much publicity that it's even got a new expansion coming out after over a decade of silence.

From the same minds that produced Age of Empires, Age of Mythology puts you in charge of ancient warriors and pantheons in a struggle to conquer the map. Gather food, wood, gold and Favor from your Gods in order to expand, conquer and acquire. New to the format are Myth Units and God Powers: use your accumulated favor to obtain unique improvements and powerful creatures from legends. Call upon your Gods to create food from nothing, plagues of locusts or rain fire from the skies on your enemies.

In the game's 13 years of existence, it has seen 2 expansions: The Titans, and more recently Tale of the Dragon. The Extended Edition comes with The Titans expansion, which grants access to the Atlantean Civilization, an offshoot of the Greeks who have been abandoned by the traditional Gods and choose to worship the precursors to the Olympians, the Titans. As well, the Extended Edition has new online support, allowing you to play games with people from across the world and upload to Twitch immediately.

reviewText: As a player who was enjoying this game since the early 2000's I was extremely excited to see its revival coming on steam. Though I still have the disks from back in the day, I was still excited to see the improvements on this game. After playing it for a little while I noticed multiple problems however. The game has some bugs and frame drop issues that were not in the previous disk versions. Though I absolutely love this game, I am not sure if the $30 price tag is worth it for essentially the same game you could have gotten in 2003. For all Veteran AoM players, this being brought back is amazing, regardless of the limited changes. I would still suggest it to any new players also, though, it is extremely fun and dynamic. This game pretty much was my childhood so I am a bit biased, though I believe this is arguably the best RTS I have ever played.\n\n9.5/10

reviewText: NOSTALGIA ALERT!\nAlongside a other notables mentions such as Age of Empires II and Empire Earth this is literally one of the founding pillars of real-time simulated strategy games. People really need to appreciate that this game comes from 2002 and Steam deserves extra kudos for putting it up on sale. Would recommend this to anyone who likes real-time strategy as it really did set a concrete standard or them earlier on this millennium. Diverse gameplay, I dare say even Age of Empires III may of even glanced over at this at took some of it's ideas >_> One bad thing is that there is a limit on housing and forced limits on town centres so you -pretty- much never get massive battles. Minus that, and expected issues with anything this old, it's a solid game.

reviewText:
This game is an RTS, similar to Age of Empires and games like that. I used to paly this back in the day when it was new.

There are 4 cultures to pick from: Greek, Norse, Egyptian, and Atlantis.

I like it because it uses real-world mythological creatures (although Atlantis is just a whole bunch of Pagan stuff mashed together) in the ways that warrior cultures would realistically use them: For instance, Hydra are used in a simliar fashion that Hannibal (NO, NOT THE DUDE FROM THE A-TEAM) used elephants, but they grow heads sometimes when they kill a unit, and each new head give them a more powerful attack.

Pros:

- Fairly simple to understand and start playing
- The campaigns are fun, and also teach you a little about mythological history (e.g. you have to collect a piece of Osiris in one of them)
- The Single/Random maps can be a great way to kill a few minutes, or an hour
- This version includes all the expansions/DLC
- Voice acting is pretty good, even if the script's a little cheesy
- The Devs are pretty active compared to a lot of other game communities

Cons:

- Last time I played this over LAN (and I mean THIS edition of the game), it was incredibly jerky. It didn't lag, but it did stutter. Totally playable, but not entirely fun. The latest patch apparently deals with this, but I haven't had time to test it and don't know when I will be able to again.
- The extra lighting effects, while excellent, MAY mean that the game has a much higher 'minimum spec'. Having said that, most modern computers should be okay.

reviewText:
Gameplay is virtually unchanged since its original release in 2002, leaving the balance (or unbalance) of the game intact. Because of this, and since the original game still runs on modern computers in HD resolutions, I'll be focusing entirely on what this installment brings to the table.

1. Improved visuals: But not really.

Much like the AoE2 re-release, Mythology was given a visual overhaul by the new studio. What this means is that they've tacked on new graphical features, without much considering of how this will benefit players. You'll see things such as GLOBAL LIGHTING and BLURRY WATER FILTER. Whether these really improve anything lies mostly in the eyes of the beholder; but for those who played the original, the new look will be discomforting and sometimes hindering (on certain maps, your units will be difficult to see).

2. Social gaming: A.k.a. the Steam Experience".

Because custom maps is half the fun
hoursPlayed: but unlike the visual improvements
voteText: this is actually a feature that is only beneficial
helpfulPercent: and does not hinder anyone who's not interested in it. So
votesHelpful: in that sense
votesTotal: this is the best thing to come out of the Extended Edition. However
votesFunny: it does not - and will not ever - weigh heavily enough to be worthy of the 30€ price tag.\n\nBut what about all the other awesome Steam-exlusive features that you won't find in the original 2002 release? Because a PC game without achievements and trading cards doesn't belong in 2014 - said no one ever

hardly a worthy selling point.

3. Extended Features: Watch other people play.

Just as Age 2 HD was given Twitch Integration

and also provides tenfolds more options than any integrated feature ever will.

In conclusion: Don't waste your money

reviewText:
Minus playing the scenario's (never crashed once for the story scenario's at least) through for a decent story / play, this game seems to love to crash when you play VS games >>>>>>A LOT<<<<<<< If you remember to save it every 5 minutes or so (lolwut) it isn't a big deal I guess. Seems like the same memory leak that was around when it first came out. Sometimes it happens randomly, other times it crashes out if I play 1 AI game after just playing a game. Sometimes I can restart the game, then play another match with no issues, other times it will crash anyways. I mean who wants to pay for a game that cannot even be played half of the time, who wants to put hours into a match to see it crash and lose all progression???

What is weird is, when I bought the original AoM and the expansion I never had it crash at all, not sure what is up there, maybe it hates windows 10 as much as the rest of us do? Which brings up another fun thing, I had one hell of a hard time getting this game to install, ended up doing a system restore just so I could even play this game.... For a bit at least, then I see my desktop backround again :p


After my latest crash, I just don't have the energy to go back and replay however long ago it was from my last save point I had to make, just in case..... So I write an angry review instead.



1/5 stars till someone fixes that bulls***
I cant in good conscience recommend a broken product to people (maybe if its on sale dirt cheap whatever then).

5/5 for any RTS lover who doesn't mind replaying the same thing they just did 4 hours ago due to the game crashing (lolz)

reviewText:
- The multiplayer is already dead. You have 4 games up in the lobby at best against mostly inexperienced players that don't stick around. The original one has gameranger with a stable community and dozens of games up all the time.
- It's unstable and prone to crash. Bravo Microsoft.
- The FPS will occasionally sinks even on up to date systems. The original can play at 60 FPS on any toaster created this century.
- It's as if someone designed the new menu on powerpoint. There was nothing wrong with the old menu.
- It has shadows. Yeeeeah. The AA is unnoticeable. The cheap water effect they tacked on top of otherwise untouched 15 year old assets is an eyesore.
- It costs 25 dollars more than the original version.

Seriously considering a refund.

There's a good chance that you, yes you reading this, already own this game. It's under that dusty pile of old CD-Roms. No really go take a look. You don't need to buy this one if you already have it.

reviewText: Age of Mythology is perhaps one of my favorite games of all time and I can honestly say that the Steam version is absolutely perfect. It has the expansion pack and everything. It plays just as it did on the original disc. I can't find anything to complain about. Even online multiplayer is still functioning and working perfectly. I would absolutely recommend this game. This is one of the best old school RTS games on Steam along with Rise of Nations and Age of Empires 2 & 3. I can't praise this game enough and I am truly grateful that I can play this game without any issues or hiccups as well as having a fresh aspect in achievment which make you want to play even more and adds even more replay value to this already extraordinary game. I highly recommend, especially if you're a fan of Age of Empires II. Rise of nations is also a game that comes to mind although the mechanics are different. This game is much more like Age of Empires II.

reviewText:
Age of Mythology is a very good RTS at its core. for new players. often good amount of stratergy is required to win. you wont do so well if you just spam 1 unit to win. each of races and gods feel differnt enough to paly. all of support differnt units, upgrades and god powers to wield each game.each of the game modes also feel differnt enough to play. the editor is thought of and quite easy to use to create simple scnerios. this allows for many maps and campagns to litter the workshop many of which are quite good. however if you want to create my complex maps with edited units and even cutscenes there is no totorial  so you may need to look i up online. the campaign for aom is pretty good. i wont lie the sotry is know masterpiece however the missions themselves are quite fun. each of them fel very differnt and have unique objectives rather then just build large army and storm the enemany base. the is a large variety of maps to play on even includes a random map generatoer which randomly creates a map for u to play on however these feel too similar after a time.
for returning aom players there is really nothing new for you. the only things changed is improved graphics, a day night cycle which can be annoying and golden gift campaign if you didn't have already. you an look forward to owning the new expansion though. as well as the includ of achievesments. while i like achievements in games and are a bit of acheivement hunter at times ifelt these acheivements were lame. the were flat out uninteresting. with no unique or funny names and basic goals that were just time consuming. you only have to winas and beat each god 10 times complete all campigns (theres 4) do some multiplayer  kill and lose some stuff and play and win game modes. pretty lame
the ai is ok but can be bad. on easy they spam caravens and always buy to the same units and never attack unless in water or a wonder has been built. medium is a huge change frim easy however i didn't find too much of difference between difficulties from there. they often uy very few myth units as well never seeming to have more then 4 in their armies at once.
multiplayer is also ok. is very differnt expirence from the ai as most humans players are alot harder to beat as they should be. however lag and frame drops plauge this so their a few people playing online.i sometimes get frame rate drops during attacks in single player as well which can be annyoing.
the cheat codes and credets are rather amusing in this game. i never watch or use either of them however after hearing things about them i sued them and found quite funnny. for the credits its only on the orginal ones and you have to get to the end of them before the humour kicks in
to sum AOM is a great game. one of the better rts out their.  you have never owned or played aom then this is a good game to buy. if you already own and play aom then im not really sure that this is worth the price. you would be playing 30 % for next to no new imporvements however you wopuld get access to tales of the dragon should that be free. its porbably better to wait for sales

Edit with the new Dlc being released this game became ver dissapointing. the game prompts you to buy the DLC very often even breaking entire matchs with messages and units. upon buying the dlc i liked the new civilisation and maps how ever the campagn and story was quite lame. also this DLC was very prone to bugs and crashes with some making the new civilsation as i have or even the whole game unplayable
Edit 2 i fixed thebug that caused the chinese civilastion to be unplayable however i had to delete all the mods as many conflicted with it. this deletes the prupose of the workshop sadly
